Request seeks the records described below: 1. Copies of all documents in Amtrak's possession that support, discuss, explain, analyze, interpret, or directly relate to how and when to offset or deduct Federal Employees Compensation Act (FECA) wage loss payments paid by the Office of Workers Compensation Programs (OWCP) when computing interest under the Back Pay Act of United States Code 5 CFR 550.805 and 5 CFR 550.806 2. Copies of all documents that discuss whether or not FECA/OWCP workers compensation wage loss payments should be deducted because ther are not specifically mentioned in the regulations or law. 3. Copies of all documents that discuss whether or not FECA/OWCP workers compensation shoud be treated as "erroneous payments," like federal pension or disability benefits. 4. Copies of all documents that discuss whether or not FECA/OWCP workers compensation payments should be treated as "administrative offsets". If Amtrak does not have the above documents, the requester would like the following information: 1. Does Amtrak use the US Office of Personnel Management (OPM) Computation of INterest on Back Pay System. 2. If so, does it deduct FECA/OWCP workers compensation wage loss payments in computing Back Pay Act interest? 3. If Amtrak deducts or offsets FECA/OWCP workers compensation wage loss payments in computing Back Pay interest how does it deduct or offset such payments:  a. Before the calculation of any Back Pay Act interest?  b. After the calculation of Back Pay Act interest?  c. By inserting the total FECA/OWCP workers compensation paid, into the "Total outside earnings" slot contained in OPM's Computation of Interest on Back Pay System computer program reflected in attached Exhibit B 4. If Amtrak deducts or offsets FECA/OWCP workers compensation wage loss payments in computing Back Pay Act interest, does it forward the deduction or offset back to OWCP?

Request seeks: Amtrak's policy for off-duty and retired federal law enforcement officers to be able to carry a concealed firearm under the Law Enforcement Officer's Safety Act (LEOSA), 18 USC 926b and 18 USC 926c. 1. What is Amtrak's current policy? Is this just an Amtrak policy or is it based on a federal statute, rule, or regulation? 2. If off-duty/retired Law Enforcement Officers not on official business wishing to carry concealed under LEOSA are not allowed per Amtrak policy, what provisions are available for law enforcement officers to check firearms when booking and traveling the same day or booking less than 24 hours before travel? If not allowed to check the firearm because 24 hours notice not given, the LEO's only recourse is to carry concealed on-board or go unarmed at their destination. 3. What is Amtrak's plan for ticketed off-duty/retired law enforcement officers to physically protect themselves and others when confronted with an armed gunman/active shooter on-board a traveling Amtrak train in a contained area with locked de-boarding doors? Especially since there is no physical security screening for firearms for the general public beyond the very limited application of TSA's Visible Intermodal Prevention and Response (VIPR) teams. 4. Does Amtrak provide consistent, effective enforcement of it's firearm policy throughout the year? It is common knowledge off-duty and retired law enforcement officers almost always carry concealed on Amtrak throughout the year and even more predominately during the yearly National Police Week held in Washington, DC. These 1000's of off-duty and retired officers travel round-trip on Amtrak from Boston, New York City, and Philadelphia to DC. 5. If Amtrak Policy is to allow travel for only official business, why is there on the LEO Traveling Armed Request, Official Police Business question, a selectable tab stating Travel is not for official police business and allowing the request to be submitted? Please answer these questions along with providing a PDF copy ofthe current Service Standards for Train Services & Onboard Service Employees manual applicable sections on law enforcement carrying firearms and weapons on-board trains, and also the section on baggage handling of firearms. Email response and attachments is authorized.

Medical Examiners office, which when viewing Dr. Simon said it was an accident. She also took the film to Phila. for my grandson John McKinney, Jaclyns brother. Helen could not answer the questions that I need answered. Jaclyn had a baby on April 25, 2018, and now Ashley has no mother. I will list the things I need in a report, answered and sent to me. Please, right away. We have a baby in foster care and I need answers to the DHS Dept. so they do not put Ashley up for adoption. I am 82 years old & I hardly ever get out of house. Hard to breathe when I walk & I can't walk by myself & I am on oxygen 24/7. Limited to phone calls & writing letters. Very important to get a quick response. 1. On June 2nd at 8:00 Amtrack [sic] was called by what train Co. They reported woman walking on tracks. They Amtrack [sic] responded by calling calling the 24th Dist. Police, who said they didn't see anyone. I called the 24th Dist. & they do not have a record of this, so they say. 2. New Jersey Transit stopped at 11:55 PM to report about a body on track. Train operator #4697. I need to know what track the train was on. I was told Jaclyn was on 3rd. She laid on the tracks from 9:05 to 11:55 PM. How come he saw her and the Norfolk Southern didn't. Wouldn't warnings have been sent to all tracks that would be in the area of 3633 I Street from 8:00 PM on to be very cauctious [sic]. 24th Dist, came out at 12:25 or close & the Detectives around 1:15 AM. Have a report of the 1st 2 officer. But Detectives tell me they don't give reports. 3. I need to know how many trains ran in the 3633 I St. area in Phila. from 7:30 PM to 12 midnight. I need to know their names & the tracks they were on. 4. How many cars were on the Norfolk train running on the Conrail Line. Was it just an engine or were their freight cars connected to engine? 5. Can you find out from the 24th district why they told me they have no report on the 8:00 PM call to them The case number DC 2018-24-045-956 Amtrack [sic] would not lie about that. 6. FROM 9:00 PM TO 11:55 PM IMPORTANT WHERE THERE ANY OTHER TRAINS AFTER NORFOLK SOUTHERN ON THE TRACK WHERE JACLYN WAS. I have asked 6 questions. Please send me your report and all the answers of the train companies. Appreciate it very much and I need this report almost immediately. It will be 2 months sense it happened or June 2, 2015. P.S. The 24th dist. put Jaclyn death at 1:30 AM on June 3rd which is incorrect.

Request copies of the National Railroad Passenger Corporations financial records concerning unclaimed, uncashed, undeliverable, and/or outstanding funds or obligations due back to non-individuals (businesses), including any and all: 	Checks or warrants issued for payments on obligations incurred by any National Railroad Passenger Corporation agency, department, office, or other authorized authority that have remained outstanding. 	Checks that have been canceled pursuant to the Limited Payability statute. 	Amounts on deposit that are held in trust for recipients whose whereabouts are unknown, including instances in which payment was never attempted, payment was never requested, and/or instances when payments were returned as undeliverable.  Such payments may relate to (but are not limited to) vendor payments, refunds, overpayments, cash deposits, cash escrows, and unsuccessful electronic fund transfers.  PwC is ONLY interested in outstanding obligations/funds that meet the following criteria: 	Amount is greater than $4,999.99. 	Payee retains the right to claim the funds. (i.e. The payment has not been replaced, was not issued in error, and/or the obligation to the payee has not been voided by law.). 	Is owed/payable to a business (companies, corporations, partnerships, etc.; we are not interested in payments owed to individuals or government entities) 	Has remained outstanding for a period of six months or longer. 	Are not in the process of being reissued, to the best of your knowledge. 	For checks canceled pursuant to Limited Payability statute, we are only interested in funds/obligations dated and/or issued between 1/1/14 to the most recent canceled date available.  The appropriate report from your accounting database should include the following if available/applicable: 	Payee name (Required) 	Amount (Required) 	Original payment date (Required) 	Identifier that can be used to internally identify payment (check #, voucher #, invoice #, etc.; we only require the bare minimum information needed for your office to internally identify payment) 	Address  PwC is not seeking any records which could invoke a personal privacy exemption. None of the information requested by PwC will be used to solicit owners or third parties. If any of the requested information above is not subject to FOIA, please provide all segregable portions of otherwise exempt material. Please also confirm when and how frequently the requested records would be updated.

FOIA- (B) In making any record available to a person under this paragraph, an agency shall provide the record in any form or format requested by the person ifthe record is readily reproducible by the agency in that form or format. Each agency shall make reasonable efforts to  maintain its records in forms or formats that are reproducible for purposes of this section. FOIA- (8)(A) An agency shall - (i) withhold information under this section only if - (I) the agency reasonably foresees that disclosure would harm an interest protected by an exemption described in subsection (b),· or (ID disclosure is prohibited by law,· and {ii)(l) consider whether partial disclosure ofinformation is possible whenever the agency determines that a full disclosure ofa requested record is not possible ·, and (ID take reasonable steps necessary to segregate and release nonexem pt information: and (B) Nothing in this paragraph requires disclosure ofinformation that is otherwise prohibited from disclosure by law, or otherwise exempted from disclosure under subsection (b)(3). FOIA- (3) Each agency shall make each such report available for public inspection in an electronic format. In addition. each agency shall make the raw statistical data used in each report available in a timely manner for public inspection in an electronic format, which shall be made available- "(A) without charge, license, or registration requirement,· "(B ) in an aggregated. searchable format: and "(C) in a format that may be downloaded in bulk ",· I request to know from the year 2015 to Present, has any Lead Service Attendant within the Washington D.C. crew base and Chicago Crew Base only; 1a) Has any person male or female applied for a position in which they are no longer a Lead Service Attendant and accepted into another position within the company? i.e. John Doe is hired on as a Lead Service Attendant and subsequently applied for a position as Stations Agent or Conductor and so on. Unity Electric Discount, LLC (Unity) is appealing FOIA's ruling to withhold portions of the records that Unity requested, based on FOIA Exemption 4. Exemption 4 protects trade secrets and commercial or financial information that is that is obtained from outside the government and that is privileged and confidential. Unity's position is that Unity should be provided contract information on all power procurement contracts between CES and Amtrak over the period August 22, 2013 through December 31, 2017. Unity never violated the CES/Unity agreement. CES breached its duty and obligation as they for some reason stopped providing Unity this Amtrak power procurement information. This information will verify all CES and Amtrak contracts executed during the period October 22, 2013 and December 31, 2017. Note that the information we are requesting is the same information we had once requested and received from CES and/or Amtrak, and it was not privileged, confidential, or providing trade secrets. Other considerations for our appeal follow: 1)	Unity selected CES to be our partner to win Amtrak power procurement contracts. 2)	Unity's role included: identifying Amtrak opportunities; arranging meetings and conferences between CES/ Unity, and Amtrak energy procurement staff /consultants); assisting in RFP analysis and pricing; and, providing the minority business inclusion component for CES and Amtrak. 3)	Unity entered a subcontractor agreement with ConEdison Solutions to provide power supply for any Amtrak RFPs/Quotes/Confirmations. This agreement was effective over the period August 22, 2013 to December 31, 2017. 4)	According to the Unity /CES agreement, "unless prohibited by Amtrak, Unity was required by Amtrak and the CES/Unity agreement to provide Unity copies of all procurement-related documents (including SBD preference or set-aside evaluation factors, customer account information, requested product description, and contract term and structure), or from Con Edison Solutions if ConEdison Solutions has itself received these documents directly from Amtrak". (See attached Unity/CES Independent Contractor Agreement, Item 8) 5)	Unity was provided contract information on the Amtrak 30th Street Station contract, and pricing information on RFPs. 6) It is unfair for CES or Amtrak to refuse to give Unity information which Unity is entitled to per the CES/Unity contract arrangement. Unity does not agree with CES' or Amtrak's reason for not providing this information to Unity, especially given the provisions of the CES / Unity agreement as stated in 4) above.

This email is to inform you a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), 5 U.S.C. §552(b), request has been received for information contained in OSHA Inspection No. 1584147 from March 2022. Pursuant to the procedures in 29 CFR Part 70.26, incorporating Executive Order 12600, 3 CFR 1988, Comp. p. 235, OSHA is providing you of written notice that it has records that originated from Amtrak and/or their representative which may be subject to Exemption 4 of FOIA. We have determined that the OSHA file contained the attached pages, which FOIA Exemption 4 may protect from disclosure. Exemption 4 requires OSHA to withhold trade secrets and commercial or financial information that is confidential or privileged and is obtained from a person. FOIA requires we review a number of factors in determining whether Exemption 4 is applicable. Please respond to the questions to assist us in evaluating whether Exemption 4 is applicable to the documents requested in this FOIA request. 1. What specific information in the documents or the document itself do you consider a trade secret? 2. What specific information in the documents or the documents itself do you consider confidential or privileged commercial or financial document/information? 3. Which documents or information within the documents do you customarily and actually treat as confidential? 4. Did you provide these documents to OSHA under an assurance or expectation of confidentiality from the government? 5. Do you consider the EIN, CAGE Number and number of employees confidential? Because the FOIA contains specific time frames in which we must respond, we need to have your views with in seven days. In the event that you fail to respond to this notice by COB March 29, 2023, OSHA will have considered you to have no objection to the disclosure of the listed documents and we will make said disclosure by March 30, 2023. Additionally, your response to this letter may also be subject to the FOIA. Please reply directly to my attention, Ms. Lisa Ceaser, ceaser.lisa@dol.gov. You may also contact me with any questions regarding this request.  (Date Range for Record Search: From 3/27/2023 To 3/27/2023)

Dear Ms. Eleanor Acheson: This is an appeal to the denial of request 23-FOI-00336. The decision was made in error and the external video of the Amtrak train must be released under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA). The goal of FOIA is to promote disclosure of information by the government and its agencies. FOIA mandates that agency disclose records on request unless the requested information falls within the nine listed exemptions. The United States Supreme Court held these exemptions are explicitly made exclusive and must be narrowly applied. Milner v. Department of Navy, 131 S.Ct. 1259, (2011). Expanding the scope ofFOIA is intended to create a citizen-centered and results-oriented approach that improves service and performance while avoiding disputes and related litigation. Exec. Order No. 13392, 70 FR 75373, reprinted as amended in 5 U.S.C. § 552. The video sought in request 23-FOI-003336 pertains to the external video from an Amtrak train that struck a passenger vehicle. Neither of the claimed exemptions, b(5) or b(6), to withhold the video are applicable in this case. The b( 5) exception cannot apply because the video does not pertain to any inter or intra-agency memoranda or letters. Nor does the video include any relevant personnel or medical files that would constitute a clearly unwarranted invasion of personal privacy. FOIA exemption b( 6) is applicable only where the files are highly personal. Dep 't of State v. Washington Post Co., 456 U.S. 595 (I 982). Moreover, the requirement that disclosure causes a "clearly unwarranted" invasion of privacy places a thumb on the scale in favor of disclosure. National Archives and Records Admin. V Favish, 541 U.S. 157, 165-66 (2004). Because the occupants of the vehicle were on a public road at the time of the accident, they were not subject to a constitutionally protected privacy interest. Katz v. United States, 389 U.S. 347 (1967) (holding that what one voluntarily exposes to the public is not subject to Fourth Amendment privacy protections). Without any privacy interests to protect, the b( 6) exemption cannot apply. Therefore, the video requested in 23-FOI-00336 must be disclosed. Notably, Rush County is named in the tort claim notice. This video is necessary for Rush County to defend itself in litigation. Failure to produce the video will result in harm to Rush County. Rush County is entitled to attorney fees following Amtrak's failure to abide by FOIA. 5 USCÂ§ 552(a)(4)(E). (Date Range for Record Search: From 1/9/2024 To 1/9/2024)

Dear Ms. Acheson, We are in receipt of your November 13, 2023, email letter in response to Delta Dental of Pennsylvania's (DDP) November 3, 2023, FOIA request under D.C. Code § 2-531 to 2-540. According to the letter, Amtrak is withholding the request information "entirely" under FOIA Exemption 4. DDP does not agree with Amtrak's decision and as such, files this appeal pursuant to D.C. Code§ 2-537 and 49 CFR §701.10. First, it is improper to deny the request entirely because Exemption 4 under FOIA covers only two categories, 1) trade secrets and 2) commercial or financial information. This would include, for example, confidential pricing information, internal processes and procedures, financial statements, etc. The exemption, however, would not include proposals publicly available, cover letters, sample forms, etc. Any confidential information or trade secrets can be redacted from the documents. Further, Exemption 4 does not cover internal documents such as internally produced notes, metrics, surveys regarding the proposals and evaluations of the proposals. If these documents contain any specific protected information, it can be redacted here as well. For the above-mentioned reasons, DDP appeals the denial and formally requests Amtrak comply with the provisions of D.C Code§ 2-534 to 2-540 by providing the entire requested record either with information deemed to fall under Exemption 4 redacted, or providing all documents that,do not fall under the exemption as discussed above. If you have any questions or would like to discuss further, please do not hesitate to contact me directly. My contact information is listed below. (Date Range for Record Search: From 2/22/2024 To 2/22/2024)

Dear Executive Vice President Acheson: Pursuant to the federal Freedom of Information Act, 5 U.S.C. § 552, I hereby appeal Amtrak's (b) (5) withholdings in Cato request 24-FOI-00169, regarding the Amtrak Texas High-Speed Rail Corridor project. In its February 21, 2024, response to Cato, Rebecca Connor of Amtrak's FOIA office stated as follows: "We are withholding this information in full under FOIA Exemption 5." Ms. Connor did not explain in any further detail the specific (b) (5) invocation she relied upon to deny the records in question. Our reading of the available facts involving the parties in this case leads Cato to conclude that the privileges of 1) attorney work product, 2) attorney-client privilege, 3) confidential commercial communications, and 4) Statements of fact made to the government during an air crash investigation are not applicable in this case. Accordingly, this appeal is centered on what appears to be a deliberative process privilege assertion by Ms. Connor. The deliberative process privilege only applies to records that are predecisional--records "prepared in order to assist an agency decisionmaker in arriving at his decision." (Renegodation Ed v. Grumman Aircraft Eng'gCorp., 421 U.S. 168, 184 (1975). Federal courts have ruled that purely factual material" that does not reveal the deliberative process is not protected by this exemption." (Morley, 508 F.3d at 1127 (quoting Paisleyv. CIA, 712 F.2d 686,698 (D.C. Cir.1983)), vacated in part on other grounds, 724 F.2d 201 (D.C. Cir. 1984). Thus, the application itself, any purely factual material related to it, and Amtrak's final determination correspondence are all responsive to Cato's request. On March 15, 2022, AG Garland issued a memo to all agency and departments instructing tl;lat with respect to the implementation of the 2016 statutory updates to the FOIA, "Information that might technically fall within an exemption should not be withheld from a FOIA requester unless the agency can identify a foreseeable harm or legal bar to disclosure. In case of doubt, openness should prevail. Moreover, agencies are strongly encouraged to make discretionary disclosures of information where appropriate. Amtrak clearly failed to adhere to the AG's instruction in response to Cato's request, and it in no way indicated the specific, articulable foreseeable harm that would result from the release of the information at issue. Accordingly, for all of the above reasons I appeal the (b) (5) withholdings in this request. In order to help to determine my status to assess fees, you should know that I am Senior Fellow and scholar at the Cato Institute, an IRS-recognized 50l(c) (3) nonprofit educational and public interest organization. As I am employed by an educational or noncommercial scientific institution, this request is made for a scholarly or scientific purpose and not for a commercial use. I request a waiver of all fees for this request and certify that my statements concerning the need for fee waivers are true and correct to the best of my knowledge and belief. Disclosure of the requested information to me is in the public interest because it is likely to contribute significantly to public understanding of the operations or activities of the government and is not primarily in my commercial interest. Whenever possible, please provide the requested information in electronic Portable Document Format (PDF). If my request is denied in whole or part, I ask that you justify all deletions by reference to specific exemptions of the act. I will also expect you to release all segreg (Date Range for Record Search: From 3/12/2024 To 3/12/2024)

This is an appeal of FOA 24-FOI-00517 that was entirely denied on two exemptions. First, I need to point out that in my 27 years of journalism, I have never received a denial on any open records request as quickly as I received this from Amtrak, which implies very little legal review or consideration of the law was done, despite the rule that FOIA must be liberally construed. Amtrak already had a predetermined response to reporters trying to do their jobs. There was no thorough understanding of the value of public records and balancing that with privacy concerns, which do not even apply here. Open access is a cornerstone of a free society. But government, especially within the past 8 years, continues to look for ways to deny without balancing this with the law. Lets deal with Exemption 6. Under Katz and its progeny, privacy for an individual requires an expectation of privacy that society will recognize as legitimate. The inquiry into whether individuals have privacy in public resulted in the third-party and plain-view doctrines. The Supreme Court held in California v. Ciraolo that viewing a marijuana field in an airplane did not require a warrant. Why? Although the field was on private property and hidden from a public street, the courts ruled that the field was still in plain view because it could be seen from the aircraft in public airspace.  The video we request is a plain-view video, and we have clarified that we dont need or want the portion of the video that you believe is a violation of privacy. When I mentioned this to an Amtrak representative, she emailed that Amtrak cannot redact videos. But the law states: Any reasonably segregable portion of a record shall be provided to any person requesting such record after deletion of the portions which are exempt under this subsection. If indeed Amtrak is not capable of editing or redacting a video, then it needs to get the software to do it, because you are required by law to segregate exactly what I am requesting. You can segregate the portion of the video that you believe is a violation of privacy. We wont appeal that action. In addition, the Amtrak official told me that this privacy exemption extends to family of the deceased, but this completely misses the point that we are not requesting what you believe is a privacy issue. Its not. But I must point out that there really is no expectation of privacy in public. Anything that happens in plain view cannot trigger the privacy exemption. This leaves little space for privacy. It certainly cannot be triggered when you consider what we are requesting. Courts have even ruled that with the advent and ubiquity of facial recognition, and high-resolution cameras, society no longer has any expectation of privacy in public. In Doe v. Reed, a group in Washington state asked the Supreme Court to block release of their names on a petition that would have required a statewide ballot referendum. Their concern was that identifying them on the petition could cause harm because they held unpopular views. The court did not agree. The irony of this use of the exemption is that the Amtrak camera presumably records everything in public. In fact, there are likely body cam videos that captured everything in public, a Ring video of a nearby home or business, a surveillance camera on top of an electrical pole, a drivers dash cam, a persons cell phone video. No one has an expectation of privacy if it is the government using the cameras and the video however it deems appropriate. Thats not how it works. Privacy extend (Date Range for Record Search: From 5/24/2024 To 5/24/2024)

The decision was made in error and the external video of the Amtrak train must be released under the Freedom oflnformation Act (FOIA). The goal of FOIA is to promote disclosure of information by the government and its agencies. FOIA mandates that agency disclose records on request unless the requested information falls within the nine listed exemptions. The United States Supreme Court held these exemptions are explicitly made exclusive and must be narrowly applied. Milner v. Department of Navy, 131 S.Ct. 1259, (2011). Expanding the scope of FOIA is intended to create a citizen-centered and results-oriented approach that improves service and performance while avoiding disputes and related litigation. Exec. Order No. 13392, 70 FR 75373, reprinted as amended in 5 U.S.C. § 552. The video sought in request 23-FOI-003336 pe1tains to the external video from an Amtrak train that struck a passenger vehicle. Neither of the claimed exemptions, b(5) or b(6), to withhold the video are applicable in this case. The b(5) exception cannot apply because the video does not pertain to any inter or intra-agency memoranda or letters. Nor does the video include any relevant personnel or medical files that would constitute a clearly unwarranted invasion of personal privacy. FOIA exemption b(6) is applicable only where the files are highly personal. Dept of State v. Washington Post Co., 456 U.S. 595 (1982). Moreover, the requirement that disclosure causes a "clearly unwarranted" invasion of privacy places a thumb on the scale in favor of disclosure. National Archives and Records Admin. V. Favish, 541 U.S. 157, 165-66 (2004). Because the occupants of the vehicle were on a public road at the time of the accident, they were not subject to a constitutionally protected privacy interest. Katz v. United States, 389 U.S. 347 (1967) (holding that what one voluntarily exposes to the public is not subject to Fourth Amendment privacy protections). When the privacy interest is minimal and the public interest is great, that disclosure of this information would constitute neither a clearly unwarranted [under Exemption 6], nor an unwarranted [under Exemption 7(C)] invasion of personal privacy. The exemptions that are part and parcel of the FOIA's broad disclosure plan are not to be used to deflect its aim that is focused on openness, not secrecy. The exemptions are exclusive, Mink, 410 U.S. at 79, not to be added to or detracted from, see US. Dept. of Justice v. Tax Analysts, 492 U.S.) to be narrowly construed with doubts resolved in favor of disclosure. See Rose, 425 U.S. at 366. Without any privacy interests to protect, the b(6) exemption cannot apply. Therefore, the video requested in 23-FOI-00336 must be disclosed. ex Notably, Rush County is named in the tort claim notice. This video is necessary for Rush County to defend itself in litigation. Failure to produce the video will result in harm to Rush County. Rush County is entitled to attorney fees following Amtrak's failure to abide by FOIA. 5 USC § 552(a)( 4)(E). (Date Range for Record Search: From 11/27/2022 To 11/27/2022)

This is an appeal under the Freedom ofinformation Act. My request dated June 17, 2024 was assigned the tracking number 24-FOI-00557. On July 1, 2024, I received a response to my request in a letter signed by FOIA Officer Rebecca Conner. I appeal the denial of my request. A copy of my request and the agency determination which is the subject of this appeal is attached for your convenience. I appeal the decision to fully deny access to the requested records because a stop work order issued by the federal government to a federal contractor does not meet the threshold for nondisclosure under FOIA Exemption 4. A stop work order issued by the government itself is not a trade secret, nor is it commercial or financial information obtained from a person and privileged or confidential. Though it could contain such information, the government has a "duty to segregate" such exempt information from otherwise non-exempt records. This duty is clearly established by the FOIA at 5 U.S.C. § 552 (b). Exemption 4 does not apply to the requested record(s), which should be fully or partially disclosed as they are created and held by the federal government for official purposes. These records contain critical information on the progress of a taxpayer-funded federal project. The existence of an official order from the government for the private contractor to stop work on this project falls well within the scope of disclosure under the FOIA. We do not dispute that the responsive record(s) could contain some information that may be exempt from disclosure under FOIA Exemption 4, such as certain cost and rate data provided by the government contractor that could be characterized as privileged financial information that was obtained from a person, and thus would be ripe for redaction. Gulf & Western Indus. v. United States (D. C. Cir. 1980). Any such information could be redacted as part of a partial disclosure of these records, as is required by the FOIA. Neufeld v. Internal Revenue Serv. (D. C. Cir. 1980) But the stop work order itself is not exempt. The first part of Exemption 4 exempts "trade secrets" from disclosure. Responsive records are not a trade secret by any definition. The fact that work on this project has stalled is not a secret, nor is it privileged or confidential - one could see this simply by standing outside Baltimore's Penn Station and observing that construction is not happening. In fact, many jurisdictions proactively disclose stop work orders by posting them online and/or by physically posting notice of the order at the site of a project. The fact that the federal government ordered for a contractor to stop certain work is not in any way "commercially valuable" information, nor is it information that is part of the contractor's "productive process." Public Citizen Health Research Group v. Food & Drug Administration (D_ C. Cir. 1983) The requested records are also clearly not "commercial or financial information obtained from a person and privileged or confidential." Even ifthere was a determination that a stop work order was commercial or financial and privileged or confidential, a stop work order issued by the government could in no way be considered "obtained from a person." The second prong of Exemption 4 only applies to "data which have not been generated within the [federal] Government" Bloomberg, L.P v. Bd. of Governors of the Fed. Reserve Sys. (2d Cir. 2010). Though requested records could certainly contain such information, as noted above, that would not exempt requested records in their entirety. That information could simply be r

FRA File No: FFRA-24-00062 Dear Rebecca Conner: The Federal Railroad Administration (FRA) has received a request under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), seeking information related to Amtraks I-20 Corridor Passenger Railway Project Grant Application. See attached. FRAs responsive records include the enclosed Project Narrative prepared by AMTRAK. FRA is required by Executive Order 12,600 and 49 C.F.R. § 7.29 to notify certain record to submitters when FRA has received a FOIA request for records that may contain trade secrets or confidential commercial information. Under this FOIA requirement, FRA asks submitters to provide written objections to the release of those records and to detail in those objections all grounds for withholding the information. FRA requests that you provide any objections you may have to the release of the attached document (or portions thereof), and if any part of the information should be withheld on the basis of FOIA Exemption 4 which protects trade secrets and commercial or financial information obtained from a person [that is] privileged or confidential. 5 U.S.C. § 552(b)(4). It is not enough to simply state that all or some of the information should be withheld. Instead, [t]he burden is on the submitter to identify with specificity all information for which exempt treatment is sought and to persuade the agency that the information should not be disclosed. See 49 C.F.R. § 7.29 (a). In accordance with 49 C.F.R. § 7.29 (b), after receiving and considering your objections, FRA will decide whether to release some or all of the document. FRA will notify you if it intends to release information over your objections. 49 C.F.R. §7.29(b). (Date Range for Record Search: From 11/21/2023 To 11/21/2023)

By exporting it to PDF, you disregarded my electronic form & format requests - and you additionally rasterized the record, which I specifically asked you not to do. OCR does not cure the destruction of the original structural metadata that makes it accessible, nor make available the parts of the records (such as hyperlinks, headers, etc) which were destroyed by rasterization. I did not consent to you making new, worse records in this way. Please provide the email in one of the native electronic email formats listed; any email software will save to them easily. My form and format request is mandatory under 5 USC 552(a)(3)(B & C) & (f)(2)(A) (E-FOIA & FOIA Improvement Act) and 29 USC 794d (Rehab Act§ 508). As for item 4, you simply did not respond at all. I therefore appeal your constructive denial for lack of any basis. Sincerely, Sai (Date Range for Record Search: From 11/8/2024 To 11/8/2024)

	Amtrak securities are not publicly traded and would have no market value if they were as no Amtrak service (including the Northeast Corridor) exhibits any prospect of generating shareholder value once on-going capital requirements are factored in. 	Amtrak's preferred stock is held by the U.S. Government. 	Amtrak's pricing is available on its website for all origin-destination pairs, classes of service and is date specific. 	Amtrak's commercial products are publicly available. 	Amtrak publishes a Five-Year Plan clearly outlining its commercial intentions to the public As outlined in note 1 to Amtrak's audited financial reports: "Without Federal Government funding, Amtrak will not be able to continue to operate in its current form and significant operating changes, restructuring, or bankruptcy may occur." It is unclear the specific reasons why exemption 4 has been applied: Exemption 4 of the FOIA protects "trade secrets (what trade secrets? ---historical accounting data has been requested) and commercial (Amtrak's pricing is publicly available-prospective marketing plans, pricing strategies or new product intentions are not requested ) or financial information (Amtrak is not publicly traded---absent on-going state and federal subsidies it would not exist) obtained from a person [that is] privileged or confidential. (again, completely unclear what is privileged or confidential)" This exemption is intended to protect the interests of both the government and submitters of information. The exemption covers two distinct categories of information in federal agency records: (1) trade secrets; and (2) information that is (a) commercial or financial, (b) obtained from a person, and (c) privileged or confidential. The class 1 freight railroads all make available very detailed financial and operational data both on their websites as well as accessible at the Surface Transportation Board despite operating in a very competitive environment. CSX, by way of example, makes available this report-an example follows: 2023-csxt-r-1.pdf Similar to the APT system this report provides account specific information and is more than 120 pages in length and the data is also available in EXCEL format. The CSX annual report is attached and is detailed-138 pages in length. The freight railroads contribute detailed commercial data in order that the Surface Transportation Board's (STB) CARLOAD WAYBILL SAMPLE can be assembled and made available. The freight railroads contribute detailed accounting information in order that the STB UNIFORM RAIL COSTING SYSTEM can be used to determine the profitability of specific movements of freight. To conclude, this is a request for historical accounting data and not prospective forecasts or commercial plans. The data requested supports existing Amtrak historical reporting data that is market specific. Fully understanding that Amtrak is "private" it does not have publicly traded shares nor is controlled by any private individual, private corporation nor publicly stock traded entities. The freight railroads are privately owned with securities that are principally publicly traded and operate in a highly competitive commercial environment. Yet, substantial data that is unredacted is made available. I would appreciate your reconsideration of Amtrak withholding this historical accounting information generated under the umbrella of protocols originating with the Volpe Center in Cambridge, MA. (Date Range for Record Search: From 12/2/2024 To 12/2/2024)

I'm a journalist with The Baltimore Sun, and I would like to appeal the response to my FOIA request with the tracking number 25-FOl-00101 . I specifically object to the redactions under exemption 4. I object to the exemption 4 redactions, because information about the condition of the bridge that is contained in the inspection reports I requested is undeniably in the public interest. I requested these documents after a chunk of concrete fell from the bridge onto a car, injuring the driver and triggering an inspection of the bridge. This sort of event and the information in the inspection reports I requested are highly relevant to the public, especially to the people who daily use the heavily-trafficked road under the bridge. This information should not be categorized as a trade secret, information that is commercial or financial, information that is obtained from a person, or information that is privileged and confidential. It should be categorized as publicly-relevant inspection reports. I don't have any objections to the redactions under FOIA exemption 6. Thank you for considering my appeal. Brooke Conrad The Baltimore Sun 509 S. Exeter Street, Suite 300 Baltimore, MD 21202 (Date Range for Record Search: From 1/9/2025 To 1/9/2025)

Request description	On 05/28/2019 I was on an Amtrak train from New York City heading home to Elkhart Indiana. I was lying down in the seat with my four-year-old granddaughter when a man fell on me. He apparently was trying to walk back to the bathroom. When he fell on me his arm went into my side and all of his weight seem to go there. The man reeked of alcohol and he had urinated in his pants. I pushed him off of me , he stood up and continue to the back of the train walking very unsteady. He fell on another lady and her child. He then collapsed in the aisle. The conductor and an attendant came to the car to see what was going on with the man. They spoke with him And they called an ambulance. They arranged for the ambulance to meet the train at a crossroad. The paramedics tried to check the man out and he refused any medical attention or examination. I spoke with the conductor and the attendant . I told them that the man had fallen on me and hurt me. They ask me if I needed any medical attention and at the time there was nothing I could do I couldnt get off the train to get medical attention because I had my four-year-old granddaughter and 10-year-old Grandson with me. The conductor arranged for the passenger to be taken off the train at the next stop. A short while later an employee came to my seat and gave me a paper to fill out about the incident. I was in very much pain over the next few days and I went to see my family physician. It was my understanding that I may have a bruised kidney or something. Since that time I have had numerous doctors appointments, including a neuro surgeon, pain specialist , and tests. I have had two CAT scans an MRI and Three x-rays. I have a ruptured disc at T7 In my thoracic spine, and a very serious displacement of a vertebrae in my lumbar spine. I am now under the care of an orthopedic surgeon, who has requested I get another MRI. He says my injuries are very serious. I would like to get the mans Information who fell on me and injured me. Amtrack would not release this information to me because of privacy reasons. I have a cumulated thousand dollars worth of bills for the tests ,doctors visits , etc. I need to get in contact with this man as soon as possible so I can try and get some compensation from him. SUSTAINED FINDINGS: This is a public records request seeking records in your agencys possession that are disclosable under Senate Bill 1421s amendments to Cal. PEN. 832.7 and 832.8. Under the California Public Records Act § 6250 et seq., this coalition of organizations engaged in the dissemination of information to the public request access to and copies of the following information in electronic, searchable/sortable format, where applicable. Each element requested should be considered severable for purposes of invoking a time extension or exemption under either local or state law. Records from Jan. 1, 2014, to present of sustained findings(1) that a peace officer committed sexual assault(2) or dishonesty-related misconduct(3). The response should reasonably include all applicable records specified by statute(4), including but not limited to: all investigative reports; photographic, audio and video evidence; transcripts and recordings of interviews; all materials compiled and presented for review to the district attorney or to any person or body charged with determining whether to file criminal charges against an officer in connection with an incident, or whether the officers action was consistent with law and agency policy for purposes of discipline or administrative action, or what discipline to impose or corrective action to take; documents setting forth findings or recommended findings; and copies of disciplinary records relating to the incident, including any letters of intent to impose discipline, any documents reflecting modifications of discipline due to the Skelly or grievance process, and letters indicating final imposition of discipline or other documentation reflecting implementation of corrective action. To the extent that your agency maintains an index of sustained misconduct that includes entries derived from findings of sexual assault or dishonesty-related misconduct, please include that record in your response. USE OF FORCE Records from Jan. 1, 2014, to present relating to the report, investigation, or findings of incidents in which the use of force by a peace officer against a person resulted in death, or in great bodily injury(5). This request also seeks records of incidents in which a peace officer discharged a firearm, regardless of whether any injury occurred. The response should reasonably include all applicable records specified by statute(6), including but not limited to: all investigative reports; photographic, audio and video evidence; transcripts and recordings of interviews; autopsy reports; all materials compiled and presented for review to the district attorney or to any person or body charged with determining whether to file criminal charges against an officer in connection with an incident, or whether the officers action was consistent with law and agency policy for purposes of discipline or administrative action, or what discipline to impose or corrective action to take; documents setting forth findings or recommended findings; and copies of disciplinary records relating to the incident, including any letters of intent to impose discipline, any documents reflecting modifications of discipline due to the Skelly or grievance process, and letters indicating final imposition of discipline or other documentation reflecting implementation of corrective action.

I submit this FOIA request to figure out why my home is being constantly subjected to train horn noise at all hours of the day and night (including after midnight when Im trying to sleep and regularly during the day when Im trying to concentrate while working form home). This has been going on for the past several months. And there is no obvious explanation. As you can from the screen shots attached to end of this letter, the tracks are not near and do not cross any road, path, or pedestrian walkway. Accordingly, I request answers to the following questions or information sufficient to answer the following questions: Track work  Is any track work scheduled to occur between Claymont, Delaware and Wilmington, Delaware on the North East Regional Line between April 2021 and December 2022? If yes, what are the expected start and end dates for those projects? For horn blowing related to track work:  At what distance away from the work site can a train start blowing its horn, e.g., 1 mile away, 5 miles away, 20 miles away?  Are crews normally scheduled to work on a track between the hours of 10:00 pm and 7:00am?  Is Amtrak required to follow a local or state governments noise ordinance laws that prohibit loud and excessive noises during certain hours?  If Amtrak has different policies for different regions of the country, the answers to these questions can be narrowed to the North East Regional Line. Noise complaints:  Does Amtrak notify the public of when track work will be conducted in their area and how long the track work is expected to last? If yes, where or how? If no, why not?  How can residents who live near train tracks inquire about train horn noise (i.e. what phone number do they call or web form do they fill out to investigate their concerns)? If no method is available, why does Amtrak not facilitate communication between the company and the residents it most regularly and strongly affects?

I hereby request all of the following information: 1. As discussed here: https://ctexaminer.com/2021/01/29/amtrak-settles-ada-claims-for-stations-in-connecticut-and-rhode-island/ (last visited May 14, 2021), which reads, "CT Examiner asked the Department of Justice and Amtrak why Old Saybrook is listed as one of the eligible stations despite not being listed in the complaint, and why New London is not listed as an eligible station even though it was listed in the complaint. Neither immediately responded on Friday.", it appears that the issue stations, for Connecticut, might vary. Why? Why would the issue stations vary like this? 2. The compensation amount, which varies based on tier, has an unknown amount, which has a maximum of $833.33, and to find the compensation amount is either multiplied by 1 or 3, depending on tier. Why is this the amount? Is there any legal, or any other reason or rationale, that this is the amount? ...and that that is the maximum amount? Could this amount be higher? (Not under the settlement, but is it possible under law?) What does this amount compensate for? 3. A. Why was this matter handled exclusively under the ADA? I note that 42 USC §12131(1)(C) defines a public entity as the National Railroad Passenger Corporation, and thus the ADA's inclusion. 3. B. With regard to the Rehabilitation Act, is that inapplicable for some reason? Lots of time numerous laws can actually apply. Presumably there is some federal funding involved here. And the owner appears to be the United States in that Amtrak is owned by its stockholders, which are only the United States. 3. C. With regard to state disability law, Connecticut disability law, is that inapplicable for some reason? It would seem that law could apply if, for example, there was enough involvement with a company or with the state, like using their property or land. It would seem there is enough for this law to apply. 4. This settlement agreement contains no opt out or other methodology to remove yourself or not be bound by the settlement. 4. A. How is that legally sufficient, permissible and compliant? 4. B. Also, under legal concepts, e.g., due process, is there an opt out anyway? As in, even though there isn't one listed, does an opt out still exist? 4. C. Please tell me how to opt out and proceed individually. 5. What is the best methodology to utilize to to address/raise issues? Would it be contacting/with the DOJ? Since the DOJ helps with this stuff. Would it be Amtrak? Who would be best to direct issues to, and seek assistance, guidance and help from? An example of an issue would be that the settlement doesn't properly or fully compensate. And to seek that compensation. 6. Punitive Damages: are they legally possible and available here? Punitive damages appear like they might be available, if not under the Rehabilitation Act, or the ADA, it appears that Connecticut law might afford such relief. Connecticut law seems like it might apply if, for example, Amtrak made itself a public accommodation, maybe by not being on federal land, like involving a business or state... and might apply because law seems to expose Amtrak to state law (note law cite/quotation a bit below). From your view are punitive damages available? Why? See: 49 U.S.C. § 28103(a)(1) "...with a conscious, flagrant indifference to the rights... of others"

I hereby request all of the following information: Questions: 1. In a settlement such as this, since the class at issue likely has a notable percent of people receiving means tested based aid, is there any exemption for received compensation allowed by law? (Or) Does the DOJ or a judge have the power to grant such an exemption? Exemption meaning the received funds simply don't count for means tested programs. I recall seeing this before. The rationale was essentially that since a discriminated party receives a means tested program benefit, the compensation should be exempt or, essentially, they would get nothing as the provided compensation would simply reduce the benefit provided proportionately. For example, in source of income discrimination for housing, it would make no sense to compensate the person, who was discriminated against for receiving housing aid, only to reduce that aid proportionately to the compensation (then there would be, effectively, no compensation). So, is there any exemption? Either already applicable or possible to be pursued/obtained? 2. Why are taxes mentioned for this case? Wouldn't taxes only be of issue if the financial amount given was other than compensation? Like the amount was punitive damages? 3. Can the DOJ aid me in pursuing fair compensation here? How can I request that aid? 4. Can the Department of Transportations Federal Railroad Administration Office of Civil Rights provide any assistance to me pursuing fair compensation here? How can I request that aid? 5. Can I pursue Amtrak individually here? Via arbitration? Do I have to complain to the Connecticut Commission on Human Rights and Opportunities first? 6. It would seem CUTPA (the Connecticut Unfair Trade Practices Act) is applicable to Amtrak. See, e.g.,: 49 U.S.C. § 28103(a)(1) "Notwithstanding any other statutory or common law or public policy, or the nature of the conduct giving rise to damages or liability, in a claim for personal injury to a passenger, death of a passenger, or damage to property of a passenger arising from or in connection with the provision of rail passenger transportation, or from or in connection with any rail passenger transportation operations over or rail passenger transportation use of right-of-way or facilities owned, leased, or maintained by any high-speed railroad authority or operator, any commuter authority or operator, any rail carrier, or any State, punitive damages, to the extent permitted by applicable State law, may be awarded in connection with any such claim..." (italics added/mine) In your view is this law (CUTPA) applicable? This section seems to make clear that Amtrak is fully exposed to state law... and that state law is applicable to Amtrak.

We request on behalf of The Associated Press under the Freedom of Information Act information concerning Amtrak's knowledge of the condition and history of a BNSF Railway (BNSF) railroad in Montana thats under jurisdiction of the Federal Railway Administration (FRA). Specifically, we are seeking records of or communications about maintenance, inspections, complaints and incident records/reports that could shed light on the circumstances surrounding the Sept. 25, 2021 derailment of an Amtrak train near Joplin, Montana that resulted in three immediate deaths and numerous injuries. For purposes of this request, the section of railroad in proximity to the scene of the derailment includes the stretch of railroad between Mile Posts 1012 and 1015 of the Hi Line Subdivision Main line, within BNSFs Montana Division. We are seeking records for the months leading up to the derailment and the period since, from Aug 1 2021 through Oct. 12 2021. Please provide electronic copies of: -- any and all maintenance records or communications concerning such records that have been received, sent or are in possession of Amtrak pertaining to the section of railroad in proximity to the scene of the derailment. ---- any and all inspection records or communications concerning such records that have been received, sent or are in possession of Amtrak pertaining to the section of railroad in proximity to the scene of the derailment. --any and all emails, complaints, letters, phone call logs or other correspondence and communications received by Amtrak from employees of Amtrak or BNSF, any member of the public or any other party concerning the condition or maintenance of the section of railroad in proximity to the scene of the derailment, including any reports of potential track anomalies or other problems experienced by passengers or employees aboard trains using the section of railroad in proximity to the scene of the derailment. --any and all records, reports or other materials, or communications about such materials, pertaining to prior accidents or derailments along the section of railroad in proximity to the scene of the derailment. --any and all communications between Amtrak and the Federal Railroad Administration regarding the Sept 25 derailment, including but not limited to communications regarding the section of railroad in proximity to the scene of the derailment. We have tried to narrow our request to the area and activities that would be most relevant to the derailment, in hopes of reducing FRAs response workload and speeding our receipt of the information. ***Please let us know at the earliest chance of any further modifications that could reduce FRAs workload and speed the process.*** Thanks for your time and all help- Matt Brown/Amy Hanson Reporters Associated Press BILLINGS, Mont. 406 696 4213 mbrown@ap.org/ahanson@ap.org (Date Range for Record Search: From 08/01/2021 To 10/12/2021)

Re:	FOIA and REQUEST TO PRESERVE EVIDENCE INCLUDING VIDEO CAMERAS  On Behalf Of: Sandra Butler 	Date of Incident: June 11, 2021 Location of Incident: Escalators on the south side of Chicago Union Station, off of Canal Street in Chicago, IL To Whom It May Concern:  Our firm is sending this request on behalf of Sandra Butler, who was using an escalator in Chicago Union Station on June 10th or June 11th of 2021 at approximately 9:00 to 9:30am, when the escalator collapsed beneath her. There are cameras that captured the incident in and around the inside of Chicago Union Station. In light of the fact that video recordings, digital photographs and similar media will likely be important evidence in anticipated litigation, we hereby demand that you or any other person or entity with knowledge or control of these items take all necessary steps to preserve any video or filmed recordings or files regardless of your retention policy. By this letter you are put on notice that you are obligated to gather, preserve, and maintain any and all original visual, documentary, and other evidence involved in the June 10th or June 11th of 2021 incident, and any electronic or other evidence, that in any way relates to the above referenced location and individuals. We request that you or any other person or entity with knowledge or control of these items take all necessary steps to preserve any and all items responsive to the above-referenced incident; including, but not limited to, any and all investigative reports, documents, photographs, camera footage, video footage, body-worn camera footage, surveillance footage or the like. You are hereby notified of the need to preserve any and all original records, physical evidence, or other data recording devices, accident reports, investigation, incident reports, movies, pictures, statements, plats of design, notes, telephone message slips, job descriptions, policies and procedures, rules & regulations, incident and/or other reports, dispatch calls/recordings, dash camera footage, body-worn camera footage and surveillance footage. 	Also, pursuant to the provisions of the Freedom of Information Act, 5 ILCS 140/1, we ask that you provide us with a copy of any and all still photographs, digital photographs and digital video or camera recordings depicting the occurrence and any and all records, reports or any other documentation captured by any video system managed, maintained or accessed by the City of Chicago or Chicago Union Station at or near the escalators off of the Canal Street entrance in Chicago, Illinois at approximately 9:00 to 9:30am on either June 10th or June 11th of 2021. I look forward to hearing from you in writing within seven working days as required by the Act. Please contact me directly if you need further information. Thank you in advance for your cooperation in this regard. The FOIA requesters information is: 	Name: Phillips Law Offices c/o Alec D. Mesrobian  (Date Range for Record Search: From 06/10/2021 To 06/11/2021)

would like the full RFI & RFQ for the Chicago Union station P3 project Master Developer for commercial elements of Chicago Union Station plan. This was originally released in October 2015. The RFI was posted on Amtrak.com and sent to local, regional and national developers includes the opportunity to redevelop the Amtrak-owned station and surrounding land parcels, as well as improvements to both passenger and employee facilities  all integrated with the surrounding neighborhoods. The RFI represents the first step in the evaluation of interested parties capable of all aspects of project delivery including an implementable Master Development Plan, design, construction, financing the potential operation and maintenance of non-rail assets, as well as identification of expansion opportunities and commercial development in surrounding areas in the West Loop. The RFI and future phases of the Master Development process is part of a larger corporate program to leverage the substantial Amtrak asset portfolio. Focused on innovative strategies for sustainable financial performance and infrastructure reinvestment, this program includes additional future opportunities at other Amtrak-owned properties that will undergo a similar Master Development process. (Date Range for Record Search: From 01/01/2015 To 01/01/2018)

I hereby request the following records: 1. All reports detailing use of force incidents by Amtrak Police personnel (Time range: January 1st, 2018 to the date this request is processed) 2. Any and all guidelines, documents, instructional/educational materials (including video), etc regarding use of force by Amtrak Police personnel (including but not limited to a "Use of Force Continuum") 3. Any and all reports regarding physical removal of disruptive, intoxicated, aggressive/violent, non-compliant/disobedient or otherwise unruly passengers from Amtrak trains. (Time range: January 1st, 2018 to the date this request is processed) 4. Any and all guidelines, documents, instructional/educational materials (including video), etc regarding removal of disruptive, intoxicated, aggressive/violent, non-compliant/disobedient or otherwise unruly passengers from Amtrak trains. (Time range: January 1st, 2018 to the date this request is processed) If the records deemed to be responsive to this request total over 100 pages, I ask that you please provide them on a rolling basis to increase record release frequency. Additionally, I formally request a fee waiver under the belief that this request in within public interest -- as the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act was recently passed (one of the biggest beneficiaries of which being Amtrak and, by extension, Amtrak Police, with the largest investment in rail passenger travel since Amtrak's inception) and more passengers ride with Amtrak as the country continues to rebound from the pandemic, I strongly believe that the public should have further knowledge regarding the 1) conduct and training of Amtrak Police and 2) the frequency of use of force/unruly passenger removal incidents. Amtrak Police is significantly less recognized, researched and documented in comparison to TSA, some major cities' transit security or even private security companies. The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Please consider this a request pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act. I am requesting all documents relating to the following incident which occurred on October 21, 2021 during travel on Amtrak Train No. 449 (the Lake Shore Limited} between Springfield and Pittsfield, MA. I was a passenger on that train. When the train reached the general vicinity of Westfield, MA the train made an unscheduled stop at a rail crossing. Out the window of the train I observed local police interacting with Amtrak personnel from the train. After about a half-hour delay, the train resumed its travel to Pittsfield. A conductor on the train informed me that a passenger had become unruly and that Amtrak personnel had to determine whether the passenger needed to be removed from the train, perhaps with the assistance of local police. It was ultimately determined that the passenger could continue to ride. When the train reached Pittsfield, where I debarked, local police were on hand and questioned the Amtrak conductor who advised the police that further action was not warranted. I am assuming that an incident of this nature, since it involved a significant delay on a long distance train, would have required the preparation and filing of a report by Amtrak personnel, such as the conductor on the train. No explanation for the delay was provided to passengers on the train, at least those seated in my car. Please advise if a fee will be charged for the copy I am requesting. Feel free to use the email shown above. Very truly yours, David J. Martel

I am a white male, approximately 6' and 200 pounds, balding and with grayish short hair. - Please provide video footage of me walking to a spot about 40' feet from the 31st/8th exit where I stop to look at my phone. An unknown individual approaches me. He walks away and then I go up the 31st/8th stairs to exit the station to street level. Please include video footage of this encounter (if there are multiple angles, please include several), and also of the unknown individual if he remained in the area after I left. Thank you. (Date Range for Record Search: From 12/17/2021 To 12/17/2021)

We would like a copy of the consulting contract awarded to Assedo Consulting (https://assedollc.com/) for West Baltimore community investment consulting on the Amtrak Douglass Tunnel project. We are a transportation research organization with a specific project (WestBaltimoreProject.org) focusing on transportation-catalyzed revitalization of the communities around the West Baltimore MARC Station, arguably the most disinvested area of the State of Maryland. And recently, we have also transitioned to a more-operational phase, with the inauguration of the HUB West Baltimore community development corporation (HUBWestBaltimore.org) to undertake development, affordable housing, and transportation upgrades. Pursuant to 5 U.S.C. Sec. 552 (FOIA), on behalf of PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP ("PwC"), I am writing to request copies of the National Railroad Passenger Corporations financial records concerning unclaimed, uncashed, undeliverable, and/or outstanding funds or obligations due back to non-individuals (businesses), including any and all: 	Checks or warrants issued for payments on obligations incurred by any National Railroad Passenger Corporation agency, department, office, or other authorized authority that have remained outstanding. 	Checks that have been canceled pursuant to the Limited Payability statute. 	Amounts on deposit that are held in trust for recipients whose whereabouts are unknown, including instances in which payment was never attempted, payment was never requested, and/or instances when payments were returned as undeliverable. Such payments may relate to (but are not limited to) vendor payments, refunds, overpayments, cash deposits, cash escrows, and unsuccessful electronic fund transfers. PwC is ONLY interested in outstanding obligations/funds that meet the following criteria: 	Amount is greater than $4,999.99. 	Payee retains the right to claim the funds. (i.e. The payment has not been replaced, was not issued in error, and/or the obligation to the payee has not been voided by law.). 	Is owed/payable to a business (companies, corporations, partnerships, etc.; we are not interested in payments owed to individuals or government entities) 	Has remained outstanding for a period of six months or longer. 	Are not in the process of being reissued, to the best of your knowledge. 	For checks canceled pursuant to Limited Payability statute, we are only interested in checks that have been issued less than 5 years ago. The appropriate report from your accounting database should include the following if available/applicable: 	Payee name (Required) 	Amount (Required) 	Original payment date (Required) 	Identifier that can be used to internally identify payment (check #, voucher #, invoice #, etc.; we only require the bare minimum information needed for your office to internally identify payment) 	Address Records Schedule (if applicable): If the requested records are routinely prepared and released on a set schedule, please provide me with the frequency of the records (e.g. monthly, quarterly, semi-annually, annually) and when the records are records are typically available (e.g. 1st day of each month, annually on December 31st, etc.). Disclaimer: PwC is not seeking any records which could invoke a personal privacy exemption. None of the information requested by PwC will be used to solicit owners or third parties. Amtrak Police Department FOIA Office 8th Floor 2955 Market Street Philadelphia, PA 19104 February 24, 2022 Dear Public Records Custodian, This is a request for public records under the California Public Records Act (CPRA). Under SB 978, a law passed in 2018, "each local law enforcement agency shall conspicuously post on their Internet Web sites all current standards, policies, practices, operating procedures, and education and training materials that would otherwise be available to the public if a request was made pursuant to the California Public Records Act."* I was unable to locate the Amtrak Police Department documents on its website. Pursuant to CPRA, I request the following records: All current standards, policies, practices, operating procedures, and education and training materials in use by the Amtrak Police Department. If these records are already available online, please provide me with the direct links to them. Otherwise, I would prefer these records in an electronic format. If there are any fees for searching or copying these records, please inform me if the cost will exceed $10. However, I would also like to request a waiver of all fees in that the disclosure of the requested information is in the public interest and will contribute significantly to the publics understanding of police practices. As the Senate Rules Committee wrote in its May 26, 2018 floor analysis**: "Making regulations of law enforcement agencies easily accessible to the public helps educate the public about law enforcement policies, practices, and procedures, increases communication and community trust, and enhances transparency while saving costs and labor associated with responding to individual requests for this information." This information is not being sought for commercial purposes. The California Public Records Act requires a response within 10 business days. If access to the records I am requesting will take longer, please contact me with information about when I might expect copies or the ability to inspect the requested records. If you deny any or all of this request, please cite each specific exemption you feel justifies the refusal to release the information and notify me of the appeal procedures available to me under the law. I can be reached via email at the email address listed on this request. I appreciate your time and look forward to hearing from you soon. Respectfully, Stanford University Libraries Relevant links * https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/codes_displaySection.xhtml?lawCode=PEN&sectionNum=13650 * * https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/billAnalysisClient.xhtml?bill_id=201720180SB978# View request history, see one related attachment, upload responsive documents, and report problems here: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Famtrak-police-department-19688%252Fsb-978-policiesurl-125308%252F%253Femail%253Dfoiarequests%252540amtrak.com&url_auth_token=AABtxl2F7AhilVfARqjDgIMWuWY%3A1nNJ3t%3ABRJuMSZ096VTWon--K0RtnhUGcsWXUKwgAASKTY_o2c If prompted for a passcode, please enter: JGLPVXUW Attachments:  Amtrak_Police_Department_of_the_United_States_of_America_Signed1 Filed via MuckRock.com E-mail (Preferred): 125308-26319874@requests.muckrock.com

March 2, 2022  Subject: FOIA Request 22-A. Adverse Determination Letters FY 2016 - FY 2022  I am submitting this request under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), 5 U.S.C. § 552 et seq., as amended. If you deny all or any part of this request, please cite each specific exemption you think justifies your decision not to release the information and notify me of appeal procedures available under the law. References cited below apply.  ***This Request will be timely for Judicial Review in twenty working days*** RECORDS SOUGHT VIA FOIA. 22-A. Adverse Determination Letters FY 2016 - FY 2022. I am respectfully seeking:  1. Records of the first 5 FOIA adverse determination letters (other than full grant) processed by your agency for fiscal years FY 2016, FY 2017, FY 2018, FY 2019, FY 2020, and FY 2021 (seven fiscal years, 35 records). a. This is an inherently simple request. Records are the FOIA Office These are antecedent records that have already been released to the Public via the determination letters themselves b. There should be no redactions as to names, email addresses or phone numbers (excluding cell numbers) of government employees, which are not exempt under (b)(6). c. There should be no redactions as to names, of non-commercial requesters, which are not exempt under (b)(6). Federal agencies have stated, I am releasing the names of the FOIA requesters as courts have held that under the FOIA requesters do not have an expectation of privacy. Stauss v. IRS, 516 F. Supp.1218, 1223 (D.D.C. 1981). d. There should be no redactions for commercial entity names, addresses, phone numbers and emails, as these are in the public domain. 2. I am also seeking a copy of this FOIA Request, which is an Agency record subject to FOIA that exists and is in the Agencys possession at the time of my FOIA request. This record is a responsive record integral to my Request. Release of the Agencys copy is not optional.  REQUESTED FORMAT.  I am also seeking a single ADA accessible PDF file by return email with: (1) a signed and dated cover letter (citing my personally assigned requester control number); (2) with record page count for all records released records (3) a copy of this request in your reply. I seek records via email in PDF format with an imbedded copy of my requests to (1) impede the agency from not addressing the FOIA Request; (2) impede the Agency from not providing the documents stated in the Agencys letter reply, and (3) make it obvious in any subsequent review what the Agency has or has not done  Under the terms of the E-FOIA Amendments of 1996, Section 5, if a document exists in electronic format, it must be released in that format upon request.  Each record must be provided as a distinct record in their native format. Emails should be provided as This request is distinctly separate from any other. Please do not combine this request with any other request in your reply. I am requesting that each element of the records sought be specifically addressed in the reply.  FEE WAIVER/ PUBLIC INTEREST/PUBLIC RELEASE. Notwithstanding my agreement to pay fees below if my fee waiver is denied, I am seeking a fee waiver due to significant public interest in this information. The subject of the requested records concerns "the operations or activities of the government. The disclosure is "likely to contribute" to an understanding of government operations or activities. There is no commercial interest. There is significant public interest. See Expedite Processing below.
