To Whom It May Concern: Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, 5 U.S.C. 552, we respectfully request access to the following information: -On April 7, 2022, Lisa Farbstein, Spokesperson in the Strategic Communications and Public Affairs office for the Transportation Security Administration, stated to Hearst Television on the record that the collection and analysis of historical Amtrak passenger manifest records in the Northeast Corridor (NEC) as described in a Memorandum of Understanding between Amtrak and the Transportation Security Administration (as cited on page 5 of the Privacy Impact Assessment for the Amtrak Rail Passenger Threat Assessment, DHS Reference No. DHS/TSA/PIA-050 dated Dec. 1, 2021: https://www.dhs.gov/sites/default/files/2021-12/privacy-pia-tsa050-amtrak-december2021.pdf ) has already occured. We request access to the anonymized analysis of this data given to Amtrak by the TSA between Dec. 1, 2022 and April 29, 2022, as described in the MOU cited above. A further description of the analysis we seek access to can be found here: https://www.tsa.gov/news/press/statements/2022/04/08/statement-regarding-privacy-impact-assessment-pia-amtrak-passenger If our FOIA request is denied in whole or part, we ask that you justify all deletions by reference to specific exemptions of the Act. We will also expect you to release all segregable portions of otherwise exempt material. We reserve the right to appeal your decision to withhold any information or to deny a waiver of fees. Due to the ongoing pandemic state of emergency and work-from-home orders, we would like to receive the information in electronic format, please. We request no communication regarding our request be conducted by mail or fax, as we are not in a position to receive it. As I am making this request as a journalist and this information is of timely value, we would appreciate your communicating with us by telephone or email, rather than by mail, if you have questions regarding this request. This information is being sought on behalf of Hearst Television, which produces news content on TV and radio stations across the United States, for dissemination to the general public. I certify that my statements are true and correct to the best of my knowledge and belief. As a member of the news media, I initially agree to pay all applicable fees up to $50.00. However, we also request a waiver of all fees in that the disclosure request is being made by a member of the media for a news-gathering purpose and would likely contribute significantly to public understanding. We look forward to your reply within 20 business days, as the Act requires. Sincerely,  Mark Albert Chief National Investigative Correspondent, Hearst Television 1100 13th St NW STE 950 Washington, DC 20005 (202) 216-4204 office (202) 793-0394 cell malbert@hearst.com  (Date Range for Record Search: From 12/01/2021 To 04/29/2022)

This is a Freedom of Information Act request submitted on behalf of our clients, Mr. David Dupre and his wife, Carol Dupre, concerning serious injuries suffered by Mr. Dupre on or about November 22, 2021. On the date in question Mr. and Mrs. Dupre traveled from Westwood, MA to Washington, D.C. on Acela train 2163. Prior to their November 22, 2021, departure the Dupres daughter-in-law made arrangements with Amtrak, in writing, that Mr. Dupre was to be taken to and from the train in a wheelchair in order to minimize his risk of falling. Upon arriving in Washington, D.C., there was no wheelchair assistance provided to Mr. Dupre and he did in fact fall and injure himself while walking from the train to the area in which he was to meet his son. Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, U.S.C. § 552, I am requesting copies of any and all of the following: 1.	Documents, reports, video, or correspondence concerning or pertaining to the injury suffered by Mr. David Dupre on November 22, 2021. 2.	Documents, reports, or correspondence concerning or pertaining to any and all ensuing internal investigations conducted by Amtrak, a/k/a The National Railroad Corporation, Amtrak Police, or their agents. 3.	Any and all policies, effective on November 22, 2021, regarding the use and/or availability of courtesy wheelchairs and/or ambulation assistance services. 4.	Any and all policies, effective on November 22, 2021, regarding assisting elderly or ill passengers. 5.	Any and all policies, effective on November 22, 2021, regarding Accessible Travel Requests. 6.	Any and all policies, effective on November 22, 2021, regarding making reservations for passengers with a disability. 7.	Any and all policies, effective on November 22, 2021, regarding station accessibility.

EDIT: per requester, should read "I request access to and copies of the formal risk assessment issued by Amtrak following its publication in September 2021 in San Clemente, California. I would like to receive the information in digital format, in batches as documents become available. I agree to pay reasonable fees for the processing of this request up to $50. Please notify me before incurring any expenses in excess of that amount. For fee categorization purposes, I am a representative of the news media. Through this request, I am gathering information for my journalistic work with SFGATE, a daily news site with 30 million monthly readers. Accordingly, I am only required to pay for the direct cost of duplication after the first 100 pages. 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(ii)(II); id. § 552(a)(4)(A)(iv)(II). Please waive any applicable fees. Release of the information is not primarily in my commercial interest and will contribute significantly to public understanding of government operations and activities. 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(iii). If my request is denied in whole or part, please justify all withholdings by reference to specific exemptions and statutes, as applicable. For each withholding please also explain why your agency reasonably foresees that disclosure would harm an interest protected by an exemption or why disclosure is prohibited by law[.] 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(8)(A)(i). I would appreciate your communicating with me by email or telephone, rather than by mail. I look forward to your determination regarding my request within 20 business days, as the statute requires. Thank you in advance for your assistance. Sincerely, Silas Valentino

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), 5 U.S.C. § 552, and the implementing regulations of your agency, The New York Times makes the following request for records: *** An year-by-year breakdown of incident reports and arrests made by Amtrak police. The following information should include, but not be limited to, name, location, description of incident, charges, dates and time of incident. FORMAT OF REQUESTED RECORDS Under FOIA, you are obligated to provide records in the format requested. See, e.g., 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(3)(B) (In making any record available to a person under this paragraph, an agency shall provide the record in any form or format requested by the person if the record is readily reproducible by the agency in that form or format.). We request all records in an electronic spreadsheet format or a CSV file. Please provide all records on a rolling basis.  RESPONSE TIME We appreciate your help in expeditiously obtaining a determination on the requested records. As mandated in FOIA, we anticipate a reply within the statutory timeframe of 20 business days. 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(A)(i). FEE WAIVER I respectfully request that you waive all fees in connection with this request as provided by 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(iii). FOIA was designed to provide citizens a broad right to access government records. FOIAs basic purpose is to open agency action to the light of public scrutiny, with a focus on the publics right to be informed about what their government is up to. U.S. Dept of Justice v. Reporters Comm. for Freedom of the Press, 489 U.S. 749, 77374 (1989). In order to provide public access to this information, FOIAs fee waiver provision requires that [d]ocuments . . . be furnished without any charge or at a [reduced] charge . . . if disclosure of the information is in the public interest because it is likely to contribute significantly to public understanding of the operations or activities of the government and is not primarily in the commercial interest of the requester. 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(iii). Disclosure to The New York Times will contribute to public understanding of the operations and activities of the government and is not in the commercial interest of the requester. EXPEDITED PROCESSING There can be little doubt that The Times constitutes a requester "primarily engaged in disseminating information." 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(E)(v)(II). There can also be little doubt that the requests relate to federal government activity; I am requesting expedited processing of this request because it concerns a matter of both urgency and of public concern. See id. "[I]f production [ of the requested records] is unduly delayed, both [The Times] and the public at large will be 'precluded ... from obtaining in a timely fashion information vital to the current and ongoing debate surrounding ... ' a high-profile government action." Protect Democracy Project, Inc. v. US. Dep 't of Defense, 263 F. Supp. 3d 293, 298-99 (D.D.C. 2017). The Times has accordingly shown a "compelling need" for the records and is entitled to expedited processing. See id.; see also, e.g., ACLU of N Cal. v. US. Dep't of Defense, 2006 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 36888, at *21 (N.D. Cal. May 25, 2006) (ordering the agency to provide expedited processing where "[p]laintiffs demonstrated a 'compelling need for the information' by showing that it was a breaking news story of significant importance to public policy").  (Date Range for Record Search: From 1/1/2010 To 10/27/2022)

I am requesting an unredacted report # 22007174. I believe I am entitled to this report. An Amtrak employee created this report when they observed my car being hit. The accident occurred in New York. In this jurisdiction, Section 66-a states that: "Notwithstanding any inconsistent provisions of law, general, special or local, or any limitation contained in the provision of any city charter, all reports and records of any accident, kept or maintained by the state police or by the police department or force of any county, city, town, village or other district of the state, shall be open to the inspection of any person having an interest therein, or of such person's attorney or agent, even though the state or a municipal corporation or other subdivision thereof may have been involved in the accident; except that the authorities having custody of such reports or records may prescribe reasonable rules and regulations in regard to the time and manner of such inspection, and may withhold from inspection any reports or records the disclosure of which would interfere with the investigation or prosecution by such authorities of a crime involved in or connected with the accident." The NY State Committee on Open Government commented on this law; their comments suggest I should have access: In sum, it is our view, based on the language of the law and its judicial construction, that motor vehicle accident reports must be disclosed in their entirety, except in two circumstances: the first would involve a situation in which portions may be withheld because disclosure would "interfere with the investigation or prosecution...of a crime involved in or connected with the accident; and the second with a situation in which accident victims names and addresses are sought for a commercial purpose. Finally, my property has been damaged and from this report it is known by Amtrak that my property was damaged. I am seeking information so I can appropriately file an insurance claim to restore my property. It would obstruct my effort for Amtrak to redact the report. (Date Range for Record Search: From 06/01/2022 To 08/01/2022)

In Nov 2019 Philip Morris Capital Corp. and HNB Investment Corp. sued NRPC in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York. The suit alleged that NRPC had breached contracts for $250 million in high speed rail equipment utilized on the Northeast Corridor. The litigants demanded payment of $92 million to cure the breach. HNB had originally contacted NRPC about this breach in 2016. Given the size of this claim and the evidence submitted to the Court by the litigants regarding its validity (including on-site equipment inspection reports), please provide substantiation as to how this significant claim was disclosed to Congress, the FRA and the general public including providing relevant copies of such documents/reports. (Date Range for Record Search: From 09/01/2015 To 03/19/2023)

On page 20 of the FY22 Management Discussion and Analysis of Financial statements the following disclosure is made: Mechanical major capital expenditures in FY2022 included $96.6 million for diesel locomotive acquisitions, $91.0 million for overhauls and replacement of Amfleet cars (single-level passenger cars built in the 1970s and 1980s), $44.2 million for overhauls and modifications on Superliners (bi-level passenger cars built in the 1970s, early 1980s and 1990s and used primarily on Long Distance trains that do not operate over the NEC), $34.7 million for new or overhauls and modifications of other locomotives, sleeper and baggage cars, and $27.8 million for lease buyouts, other passenger or baggage car overhauls and facilities repairs and improvements. For each dollar total that is disclosed (above), please provide an itemized list of each piece of equipment subject to an overhaul including the specific maintenance performed on each as the well as the dollar amount capitalized for each piece of equipment. By way of example, Amtrak's FY22-27 Service & Asset Line Plan categorizes overhauls by the following definitions-please indicate which overhaul "level" pertains to each overhauled railcar: Amtrak's Overhaul Cycle Level I (Every 4 years) The lightest overhaul includes complete rebuilding of trucks, HVAC units, brake valves, door operators and system critical components as well as heavy cleaning of carpeted surfaces and seat cushion replacement. Level II (Every 8 years) A Level I overhaul plus a complete replacement of all major components such as seats, diaphragms, windows and 480V trainline cabling. Level III (As needed) A Level II overhaul plus a complete interior upgrade or reconfiguration, including bathroom modules and any required modifications (Date Range for Record Search: From 09/01/2021 To 03/19/2023)

To whom it may concern,  I am an Amtrak conductor who is unfortunately at a midpoint crew base that is slated for closure. I'm trying to put together a case to present to Paul O'mara and Joe Morris in Chicago to fight to keep BTL open. That being said, I'm looking for specific information that might help build that case.  The specific information I'm looking for falls under a few categories. First, management in Chicago has presented to the State of Michigan and MDOT that closing BTL will save the state 2 million annually, but when asked to show the specifics behind how that closure will save 2 million, no information is forthcoming. How does management get to that 2 million in saving for closing BTL crew base? Second, and along the same lines, I was wondering if I could get the specifics for current crew bases running in Michigan? What are the current annual budgets for crews in CHR (Chicago road; that works into BTL), BTL, and PNT (Pontiac, Michigan). Not just salary for trainmen and engineers, but also the cost of transportation and lodging for said T&E for the three lasted crew bases.  Third, and still in the budget realm, what were the budgets (again including salary, lodging and transportation) of said crew bases (CHR, BTL, PNT) pre-covid? Prior to covid, the work from Battle Creek to Chicago was split evenly between CHR and BTL.  A similar case to the current push to close BTL, was experienced in Lincoln, Nebraska. A few years ago, management decided to close LNC and move that work to Denver, Colorado. Up front, they were saying that optimization was showing the company would save money running those trains out of DEN and closing LNC. That being said, two years later, they had to reverse that decision and reopen LNC bc of an assortment of unexpected costs associated with running that work out of DEN (Recrews, transportation, lodging, service recovery from late trains, etc.). Since we in Michigan feel this is a similar case to ours, we were looking for the specific financial information used to justify closing LNC initially, and then the financial information that was used to justify reopening LNC two years later. We'd rather prevent the closing of the crew base for a few years before management realizes the mistake they've made.  And last, I was looking for response time for recrewing trains out of the three crew bases of CHR, BTL, and PNT. Our hope is to show that with BTL being a midpoint crew base, the data will show that it will have a faster average response time to rescue/recrew trains thus showing the importance of keeping trainmen and engineers at a ready point able to respond to any sort of situation.  If you could help me formalize my questions in a way so as to get the information I need to present a good case to keep my and my co-workers crew base from closing, I would greatly appreciate it.

1)	A copy of the Davis Bacon and Baltimore City wage determinations applicable to the Baltimore Penn Station project. 2) A copy of all certified payroll records submitted on behalf of Contracting Specialists Incorporated for work performed on the Baltimore Penn Station project from October 1st, 2022 to present. 3) A copy of all certified payroll records submitted on behalf of Coastal Exteriors for work performed on the Baltimore Penn Station project from October 1st, 2022 to present. (Date Range for Record Search: From 10/01/2022 To 05/17/2023)

To whom it may concern, I am an Amtrak conductor who is unfortunately at the midpoint crew base of Battle Creek (BTL) that is slated for closure. I'm trying to put together a case to present to Paul O'mara and Joe Morris in Chicago to fight to keep BTL open. That being said, I'm looking for specific information that might help build that case. The specific information I'm looking for falls under a few categories. First, management in Chicago has presented to the State of Michigan and MDOT that closing BTL will save the state 2 million annually, but when asked to show the specifics behind how that closure will save 2 million, no documents are forthcoming. I'm looking for the specific documents that management is using that shows how closing Battle Creek (BTL) will save the state of Michigan and MDOT two million dollars annually. Second, and along the same lines, I'm looking for documents that show the current annual budgets for the trainmen and engineers (T&E) of the three crew bases listed. 1) Chicago road (CHR) that works into BTL for their turn, 2) Battle Creek (BTL) crew base, and 3) Pontiac (PNT) crew base. Please include documents that show current or most recent annual budgets for salary, transportation, and lodging for the three listed crew bases. Third, and still in the budget realm, I'm looking for any documents that show the budgets (again including salary, lodging and transportation) of said crew bases (CHR, BTL, PNT) for the fiscal year of 2019 (Pre-covid)? Prior to covid, the work from Battle Creek to Chicago was split evenly between CHR and BTL. A similar case to the current push to close BTL, was experienced in Lincoln, Nebraska. A few years ago, management decided to close LNC and move that work to Denver, Colorado. Up front, they were saying that optimization was showing the company would save money running those trains out of DEN and closing LNC. I'm looking for the documents used to justify the closing of the LNC crew base (should be dated around 2018, when the work was moved to DEN) That being said, a few years later, they had to reverse that decision and reopen LNC bc of an assortment of unexpected costs associated with running that work out of DEN (Recrews, transportation, lodging, service recovery from late trains, etc.). Again, I'm looking for any documents that were used as a justification to reopen LNC as a crew base, specifically looking at the unexpected costs listed previously. We'd rather prevent the closing of the crew base for a few years before management realizes the mistake they've made. And last, I was looking for documents that show the response times for recrewing trains out of the three crew bases of CHR, BTL, and PNT. Our hope is to show that with BTL being a midpoint crew base, the data will show that it will have a faster average response time to rescue/recrew trains thus showing the importance of keeping trainmen and engineers at a ready point crew base. Dear FOIA Officer, Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, 5 U.S.C. § 552, and the implementing FOIA regulations of the National Railroad Passenger Corporation, I respectfully request the following: a current organizational hierarchy chart for the National Railroad Passenger Corporation. To further narrow down the scope of the request, requester does not seek correspondence that merely forwards press clippings, such as news accounts or opinion pieces, newsletters, and published or docketed materials, if that correspondence has no comment or no substantive comment added by any party in the thread.The terms pertaining to, referring, relating, or concerning with respect to any given subject means anything that constitutes, contains, embodies, reflects, identifies, states, refers to, deals with, or is in any manner whatsoever pertinent to that subject. Please comply fully with 5 U.S.C. § 552(b). Moreover, to the extent that responsive records may be withheld in part produce all reasonably segregable portions of those records. Additionally, please provide all responsive documents even if they are redacted in full. This request is primarily and fundamentally for non-commercial purposes. As a 501c3 nonprofit, Heritage Foundation does not have a commercial purpose and the release of the information requested is not in Heritage Foundations commercial interest. The Heritage Foundations mission is to formulate and promote public policies based on the principles of free enterprise, limited government, individual freedom, traditional American values, and a strong national defense. Heritage Foundation uses the information requested and analyzes it in order to educate the public through social media, broadcast media (traditional and nontraditional) and press releases. The requested information is in the public interest because there trust in government is at historic lows, and the American people deserve transparency. Organizational hierarchy charts are critical to examine both the scope of the agency, as well as to further understand the agency's core operations in parallel to current oversight investigations. Because this is a request by a member of the news media for information of public interest, made in my capacity as an author for The Daily Signal (a major news outlet ), I actively gather information of potential interest to our Daily Signal audience, and I use my editorial skills to turn raw materials into a distinct work, and I distribute that work to our Daily Signal audience through podcasts or articles. I request that you waive all applicable fees associated with this request. If you deny this request for a fee waiver, please advise me in advance of the estimated charges if they are to exceed . Please send me a detailed and itemized explanation of those charges. If you have any questions, or feel you need clarification of this request please contact me at noreplyoversight@heritage.org.

(Alstom) is requesting a copy of the complete administrative record for Amtrak RFP # DOC750069 for the Intercity Trainset Acquisition & Technical Support, Spares, and Supply Agreement (TSSSA), including, but not limited to, the following: 	Bid Submissions. All records, including documents and other materials, submitted by all bidders in connection with their proposals or otherwise related to the subject RFP. This includes the bidders Price Proposals and Technical Proposals and statements and certifications regarding eligibility, plus offerors letters. 	Correspondence. All correspondence and exchanges between bidders and Amtrak pertaining to the subject RFP and related materials. This includes requests for clarification to bidders and pre-award bidder negotiations with Amtrak plus any materials related to negotiations including memos, notes or reports. 	Evaluation & Contract Award. All records, including documents, correspondence evaluation manuals, guidelines, forms, worksheets, and other materials pertaining to evaluation of the bids submitted by all bidders and the awarding process. This includes: o	Memoranda setting forth the evaluation criteria formula; o	Tabulations of reviews including technical & price evaluations; o	Determinations of eligibility; o	Evaluations of both Technical and Price Proposals, plus any related summaries and presentations, by the Evaluation Committee, the Contracting Officer, and any other Amtrak employees; o	Recommendations and reports of both Technical and Price Proposals plus related summaries and presentations by the Evaluation Committee, the Contracting Officer, and any other Amtrak employees; o	Inter-agency and intra-agency communications regarding evaluation or contract award or otherwise made in connection with the procurement process. 	Procurement Process. All procurement guidelines, manuals and memoranda related to RFP # DOC750069. All documents and other materials listing or ranking bidders with regard to a competitive range determination. This includes documents and other materials relating to Amtraks decision to enter into a Best and Final Offer (BAFO) stage. 	Independent Cost Estimate. A copy of any and all Independent Cost Estimates (ICE) received by Amtrak in connection with the subject RFP, plus all documents and other materials relating to said ICE. 	Proposed Contract. The contract and associated contract materials proposed to be signed. 	Contract. The fully executed contract and associated contract materials signed by the successful bidder. As noted above, this request seeks the complete administrative record for RFP # DOC750069 and does not limit its request to the items specifically identified above. Dear FOIA Officer, Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, 5 U.S.C. § 552, and the implementing FOIA regulations of the agency, I respectfully request the following: Records sufficient to identify all employees who entered into a position at the agency as a Political Appointee since January 20, 2021, to the date this records request is processed, and the title or position of each employee (to the extent that individuals have held multiple positions during this time period, identify each title or position and the time period it was held). For each individual identified in response to Requests 1 and 2 provide: 1. Any Ethics Pledge waivers, issued pursuant to Section 3 of Executive Order 13989 and Office of Government Ethics Legal Advisory 21-04, received by the individual. 5. Any ethics agreement executed by the individual; any Certification of Ethics Agreement Compliance; and any records relating to any violation by an individual of his or her ethics agreement. 6. Records reflecting any recusal determination made or issued for the individual. 7. Copies of any SF-50 forms for the individual reflecting any change in position, title, or salary, including when the employee starts or leaves a position. 8. Completed Ethics Pledge for each individual. I am amicable to a rolling production as records are available. To further narrow down the scope of the request, requester does not seek correspondence that merely forwards press clippings, such as news accounts or opinion pieces, newsletters, and published or docketed materials, if that correspondence has no comment or no substantive comment added by any party in the thread.The terms pertaining to, referring, relating, or concerning with respect to any given subject means anything that constitutes, contains, embodies, reflects, identifies, states, refers to, deals with, or is in any manner whatsoever pertinent to that subject. Moreover, to the extent that responsive records may be withheld in part produce all reasonably segregable portions of those records. Additionally, please provide all responsive documents even if they are redacted in full. This request is primarily and fundamentally for non-commercial purposes. As an investigative journalist and author, my request is in the public interest to inform the public. I would draw your attention to the memorandum, released March 15, 2022 that requires both agencies adhere to proactive disclosures for "records that have been requested three times or more, or that have become or are likely to become the subject of subsequent requests" as well as to uphold "timely disclosure of records" (https://www.justice.gov/media/1212566/dl?inline). The requested information is in the public interest because there trust in government is at historic lows, and the American people deserve transparency about the operations of the Agency. Because this is a request by a member of the news media for information of public interest, made in my capacity as an author for The Daily Signal (a major news outlet) as well as other outlets, I actively gather information of potential interest to my audience, and I use my editorial skills to turn raw materials into a distinct work, and I distribute that work to the Daily Signal and other outlets such as Breitbart and Fox News through articles or social media posts. I request that you waive all applicable fees associated with this request. If you deny this request for a fee waiver, please advise me in advance of the estimated charges if they are to exceed . Please send me a detailed and itemized explanation of those charges. If you have any questions, or feel you need clarification of this request please contact me at colinaamot@protonmail.com.

Hi, my name is Minho Kim, and Im a climate change reporter at POLITICOs E&E News.  Im doing a story that investigates the impact of heat stress on Amtrak trains. This summer had record-breaking heatwaves, and Im trying to write a story that compares the number of Amtrak train delays caused by heat-related speed restrictions from this year to other years.  It would be very helpful if Amtrak could provide information for each train delay that was caused by heat-related speed restrictions for summer 2023 and summer 2022. Summer is here defined as the timeframe between June 1 to August 31.  Specifically, Im asking the following information for each train delay that was caused by heat-related speed restrictions for summer 2023 and summer 2022: - Train number, the amount of time delayed, the location of such delay, the date and hour of delay, and the cause(s) of delay other than heat-related speed restrictions. - Summer is here defined as the timeframe between June 1 to August 31. - For each delay, Im looking for information such as this Twitter post from the official Amtrak NEC Alerts account. - I'm also requesting the average number of trains delayed per each summer because of "heat-related speed restrictions" between 2010 and 2019. -	The number of minutes delayed due to heat-related speed restrictions for each train impacted by the hot weather o	during each summer of 2023 and 2022 (June 1 to August 31). o	during each summer between 2010 and 2019 (June 1 to August 31). -	Total number of miles driven by Amtrak trains o	during each summer of 2023 and 2022 (June 1 to August 31) o	during each summer between 2010 and 2019 (June 1 to August 31). -	Total number of miles driven by Amtrak trains in Northeast Corridor o	during each summer of 2023 and 2022 o	during each summer between 2010 and 2019  (Date Range for Record Search: From 5/31/2022 To 9/1/2023)

We're interested in understanding why the Amtrak train status (in app and on website) is often inaccurate. We're also interested in knowing exactly how inaccurate it is and what it would take to fix it. Please provide the following: 1) Technical Specifications and Documentation: Any documentation, technical specifications, or flowcharts that explain how the "Train Status" tool operates, sources its information, and updates its database. 2) Accuracy and Reliability Metrics: Reports, memos, or other communications discussing the accuracy and reliability of the "Train Status" tool. This includes any internal or external audits, reviews, or evaluations conducted about the tool's accuracy. 3) Customer Feedback and Complaints: Summaries, reports, or analyses of customer feedback, comments, and complaints related to the accuracy and reliability of the "Train Status" tool. 4) Corrective Measures: Documents, plans, proposals, or communications discussing strategies, initiatives, or measures taken (or being considered) to improve the accuracy and reliability of the "Train Status" tool. 5) Vendor Agreements: If the tool or parts of its technology are outsourced to third-party vendors, I request copies of relevant contracts, agreements, or communication detailing the scope of work, performance expectations, and accountability measures related to the "Train Status" tool. 6) Internal Communications: Memos, emails, or other internal communications discussing challenges, issues, or updates to the "Train Status" tool that could provide insights into its operational challenges and potential inaccuracies. 7) The title and position responsible for the Train Status tool. Thank you!

Good morning: Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), I request Amtrak's production of the electronically-stored and/or electronically-retrievable and/or electronically-transmissible records, which are described herein below, via email delivery. Description of Requested Records I request email production of - Amtrak's written rules, regulations, policies, procedures, protocols and guidance to Amtrak representuves, which directly, expressly and specifically govern Amtrak's consideration and action on passenger requests for a religious accommodation and/or a religious exemption from Amtrak's photo ID requirement based on the Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA); as adopted and/or promulgated by and/or under the authority Amtrak's Governing Board and/or Antrak's leadership during the period covering between June 30, 2014 (which was the date on which the United States Supreme Court decided Burwell v. Hobby Lobby Stores, Inc., 573 US 682 (2014), which construed the RFRA and the date of this FOIA Request - Monday, October 16, 2023. If Amtrak's compliance with any part of my FOIA Request can be accomplished by and through referenc to any notice(s) published in the Federal Register, please provide me with a citation to such public notice(s). If, upon reasonable search(es) of appropriate databases and indices, Amtrak concludes that there are no records responsive to my request, please notify me as soon as possible. Request for Fee Waiver I further request a waiver of any applicable fee(s) based on the grounds that: (1) my FOIA Request involves fundamental, longstanding religious liberty rights guaranteed under the RFRA; (2) waiver of any applicable fee(s) would advance a compelling public interest in upholding, protecting and preserving an essential and integral part of religious liberty; and (3) I am not in receipt of a proffer of competent, substantial evidence, which would tend to establish that a fee waiver would constitute an exceptionally demand on public resources. Request for Reasonable Segregation To the extent Amtrak claims an Exemption to compliance with any part of my FOIA Request, I further request that Amtrak produce reasonably-segregable and/or redactable portions of responsive records. Request for Vaughn Index To the extent Amtrak withholds any record(s) responsive to my FOIA Request, I further request production of a Vaughn Index. Please do not hesitate to contact me with any questions or concerns. I look forward to your response. Thank you. Andres Fernandez 07046@pm.me Sent with Proton Mail secure email. (Date Range for Record Search: From 10/16/2023 To 10/16/2023)

Hi, my name is Minho Kim, and Im a climate change reporter at POLITICOs E&E News. Im trying to do a story that shows the increasing minutes of Amtrak delays due to weather-related issues, especially the number of heat-related delays. Specifically, I am requesting the following information from Amtrak: All final Electronic Delay Reporting (eDRs) submitted by train conductors that cites weather-relayed delays as the reason for delays. Please submit all information since the beginning of fiscal 2000. Please provide the information using a spreadsheet file, with each row reflecting each train that got delayed due to weather-related reasons. For each row (for each train that got delayed) I request the following information: - the train number - the actual location the delay occurred - Number of minutes delayed - Specific reasons for the weather-related delay including but not limited to heat or cold orders, storms, floods/washouts, earthquake-related delays, slippery rail due to leaves, flash-flood warnings, wayside defect detector actuations caused by ice, and high-wind restrictions. - The date of departure - The date of arrival I understand there could be multiple eDRs for every train, so please make sure the number of delayed minutes for each Amtrak train listed on a row is a final number. Thanks much! Minho  (Date Range for Record Search: From 10/01/1999 To 09/30/2023)

DDear FOIA Officer, Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, 5 U.S.C. § 552, and the implementing FOIA regulations of the agency, I respectfully request the following: Copies of all implementing directives, orders, memorandums, policies, guidance, or memorandums of understanding (MOUs) pertaining to Executive Order 14052 (E.O. 14052): Implementation of the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act. Subsequently (in relation to E.O. 14052), all directives, orders, memorandums, policies, guidance, or memorandums of understanding (MOUs), or contracts pertaining to the Infrastructure Implementation Task Force, Justice40 Initiative, or mentioning environmental justice. Please limit the timeframe of the search from November 15, 2021 to present. I am amicable to a rolling production as records are available. To further narrow down the scope of the request, requester does not seek correspondence that merely forwards press clippings, such as news accounts or opinion pieces, newsletters, and published or docketed materials, if that correspondence has no comment or no substantive comment added by any party in the thread. Please comply fully with 5 U.S.C. § 552(b). Accordingly, without limitation to the foregoing, if any portion of this request is denied for any reason, please provide written notice of the records or portions of records that are being withheld and cite each specific exemption of the Freedom of Information Act on which the agency relies. Moreover, to the extent that responsive records may be withheld in part produce all reasonably segregable portions of those records. Additionally, please provide all responsive documents even if they are redacted in full. This request is primarily and fundamentally for non-commercial purposes as a member of the media. As an investigative journalist and author, my request is in the public interest to inform the public with regard to governmental overreach. If you have any questions, or feel you need clarification of this request please contact me at colinaamot@protonmail.com.

Copies of any and all responsive documents in connection with EMT and any other medical personnel; 4.	Copies of any and all responsive documents in connection with firemen and the MTA personnel; 5.	Copies of any and all responsive documents in connection with any other safety personnel; 6.	A copy of any investigators and/or first responders field notes with respect to the accident; 7.	A copy of the accident coordinators report. 8.	Duplicate color copies of all photographs concerning the subject accident or the investigation into the subject accident by fire, EMT or ambulance personnel; 9.	Duplicate color copies of all video footage concerning the subject accident or the investigation into the subject accident by fire, EMT or ambulance personnel; 10. Dear FOIA Officer, Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, 5 U.S.C. § 552, and the implementing FOIA regulations of the agency, I respectfully request the following: All written correspondence exchanged between any State(s) and the Agency concerning the designation of the Agency as a voter registration agency, pursuant to section 7(a)(3)(B)(ii) of the National Voter Registration Act. Any and all documents that pertain to the formalization or execution of the designation of the Agency as a voter registration agency, pursuant to the requirements of section 7(a)(3)(B)(ii) of the National Voter Registration Act. Search Instructions: Please limit all searches in response to this Request from January 1, 2021, to the present. Please include the full email chain and attachments relevant to any responsive documents to provide further context. To further narrow down the scope of the request, requester does not seek correspondence that merely forwards press clippings, such as news accounts or opinion pieces, newsletters, and published or docketed materials, if that correspondence has no comment or no substantive comment added by any party in the thread.The terms pertaining to, referring, relating, or concerning with respect to any given subject means anything that constitutes, contains, embodies, reflects, identifies, states, refers to, deals with, or is in any manner whatsoever pertinent to that subject.The term record means any written, recorded, or graphic matter of any nature whatsoever, regardless of how recorded, and whether original or copy, including, but not limited to, the following: memoranda, reports, expense reports, books, manuals, instructions, financial reports, working papers, records, notes, letters, notices, confirmations, telegrams, receipts, appraisals, pamphlets, magazines, newspapers, prospectuses, inter-office and intra-office communications, electronic mail (emails), MMS or SMS text messages, instant messages, messaging systems (such as iMessage, Microsoft Teams, WhatsApp, Telegram, Signal, Google Chat, Twitter direct messages, Lync, Slack, and Facebook Messenger), contracts, cables, telexes, notations of any type of conversation, telephone call, voicemail, meeting or other communication. Please comply fully with 5 U.S.C. § 552(b). Accordingly, without limitation to the foregoing, if any portion of this request is denied for any reason, please provide written notice of the records or portions of records that are being withheld and cite each specific exemption of the Freedom of Information Act on which the agency relies. Moreover, to the extent that responsive records may be withheld in part produce all reasonably segregable portions of those records. Additionally, please provide all responsive documents even if they are redacted in full. This request is primarily and fundamentally for non-commercial purposes. As an investigative columnist and author, my request is in the public interest to inform the public regarding the agency's operations voter issues ahead of the upcoming elections.

requesting footage of the incident involving myself on May 24, 2023 at 10 pm as I exited the Amtrak train. I traveled by Amtrak on a one-way ticket departing from New York, NY (Moynihan Train Hall at Penn Station) track# 79 arriving in Charlotte N.C. The train departed from New York, NY at (7:25 am) and was to arrive to Charlotte N.C. at (8:56 pm). However the train ran late and arrived to Charlotte N.C. about 10:03 pm. I was one of the last two people to exit the train. It was myself and a 86 year old elderly woman. (Date Range for Record Search: From 5/24/2023 To 5/24/2023)

See attached regarding Amtrack Dallas-Houston high speed rail grant application. Pursuant to the federal Freedom of Information Act, 5 U.S.C. § 552, and on behalf of the Cato Institute, I request records (as defined in 44 U.S.C. § 3301) regarding the following grant application: DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION NOTICE OF AWARD For Office of Representative Jake Ellzey Date: 12/5/2023 Grant: FY22 Corridor Identification and Development Project: Amtrak Texas High-Speed Rail Corridor Locality: Dallas, Houston, TX Applicant: National Railroad Passenger Corporation (Amtrak) Grant Amount: $500,000 DOT Agency Disbursing Funds: Federal Railroad Administration DOT Agency Contact: Jonathan.Black@dot.gov Description: The proposed Corridor would connect Dallas and Houston, TX with a new, dedicated and grade-separated high speed passenger rail service. The proposed Corridor would provide new service on a new alignment, with station stops in Dallas, Brazos Valley, and Houston. The Corridor sponsor would enter Step 1 of the program to develop a scope, schedule, and cost estimate for preparing, completing, or documenting its service development plan. NOTICE TO CONGRESS OF DOT DISCRETIONARY GRANT AWARDS: This notification is provided to the Committee pursuant to one of the following requirements governing the public announcement of a Department of Transportation discretionary grant, letter of intent, or Federal Transit Administration full funding grant agreement:  (1) Currently applicable General Provision of the Appropriations Act, Continuing Resolution, or Supplemental Appropriation governing Department of Transportation appropriations, containing a prohibition on the use of funds made available unless the Secretary notifies the House and Senate Committees on Appropriation at least three full business days before the Department or its operating administrations announces any discretionary grant award, letter of intent, or full funding grant agreement from: (A) any discretionary grant or federal credit program of the FHWA, including the emergency relief program; (B) the airport improvement program of the FAA; (C) any program of the FRA; (D) any program of the FTA other than the formula grants and fixed guideway modernization programs; (E) any program of the Maritime Administration; or (F) any funding provided under the heading National Infrastructure Investments in the Appropriations Act;  (2) Section 311 of title 49, United States Code;  (3) Section 159(b) of the Wendell H. Ford Aviation Investment and Reform Act for the 21st Century (AIR-21); or  (4) Section 5334(j) of title 49, United States Code. The date range of this request is 10/1/2021 to 9/30/2023.  (Date Range for Record Search: From 10/1/2021 To 9/30/2023)

In order to help you determine the undersigneds status for the purpose of assessing fees, and by way of background, we advise that the undersigned represents certain vessel interests in connection with an allision that occurred on April 16, 2022, on the Hackensack River, in Kearny New Jersey, involving the railroad swing bridge known as the Portal Bridge, which is reportedly owned and/or operated by National Railroad Passenger Corp. (Amtrak). The documentation requested herein is needed for investigatory purposes and in anticipation of litigation and is not for commercial use. The documentation/information requested consists of the following: (1)	Recordings, or transcripts of any recordings, of any communications between the captain/crew of the Tug LIZ VINIK and the bridge operator/tender for the bridge known as the Portal Bridge on April 16, 2022; (2)	Logbooks, including electronically stored logbooks, concerning the passage of the Tug LIZ VINIK through the Portal Bridge on April 16, 2022; and (3)	Any and all documents concerning approvals, requests for approval, authorization, requests for authorization, directions, expressions of intentions, instructions, plans, permissions, communications, and/or signals, to, from, or between the captain/crew of the Tug LIZ VINIK and any agents, controllers, officials, operators, and/or tenders of the Portal Bridge on April 16, 2022.

February 16, 2024 Amtrak FOIA Office ATTN: Rebecca Conner, FOIA Officer 1 Massachusetts Avenue, NW Washington, DC 20001 Via Online Portal Freedom of Information Act Request Dear Sir or Madam: Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), as amended, 5 U.S.C. § 552, et seq., COGENCY GLOBAL INC. would like to request a summary listing for all awarded Contracts and Task Orders by Amtrak in the value of $5Million and above awarded within a three (3) year range from search date of 1/1/2021 to date. We request the data related only to the following NAICS codes 511, 512, 513, 519, 541, and 611. We request aforementioned summary listing include Contract/Task Orders: (1) Name of contract/description of work, (2) identification number if available , (3) associated NAICS code/s, (4) awarded value/obligations value (5) Name of contractor/vendor/awardee. Please release the information on a rolling basis. COGENCY GLOBAL INC. requests that you provide us with accurate copies, or a complete and accurate account of the information requested. This is a commercial request. We agree to pay reasonable search and reproduction costs; however, if these costs exceed $200, we request that you notify us before reproducing the documents. We understand that we can expect a response within twenty days of your receipt of this letter. We prefer electronic copies of the documents, but if courier or overnight delivery is necessary, please contact us for delivery or pickup information. If you have any questions about this request or require further information, please contact us at 800.494.5225 or agency@cogencyglobal.com . Thank you for your attention to this matter. Sincerely, Joanna McCall, Assistant Secretary On behalf of: COGENCY GLOBAL INC. agency@cogencyglobal.com (800) 494-5225

Please provide how Amtrak combats against the unaccountable and intimidation of executive bullying within Amtrak's executive ranks and if they have any self-awareness of mistreatment of the innocent both employee as well as the public What Bullying Is Costing Your Company When you, as the leader of an organization allow bullying to occur you create at least five problems: 1. The target of the bullying will experience a loss of confidence and an increase in stress that often shows up in health problems. Their performance will decline. They may need more time off to recover. So you have lower performance by at least one person, the target. 2. By allowing the bullying to continue you are accepting a toxic culture, prevalent Critter State, and reduced performance and morale. The people witnessing the bullying will have to choose to side with the bully, leave, risk retribution by speaking out, or remain passive and try to stay under the bullys radar. To be non-threatening to the bully they may lower their performance in some way. 3. Eventually the target will have no recourse but to leave. Research has shown that the vast majority of targets eventually leave. You now have lost a good employee and have all the costs of a new hire. 4. Plus you have the almost certain guarantee that the cycle will repeat itself. I find that organizations which condone bullying, which have prevalent Critter State, also have high employee turnover rates, far less revenue per employee, increased absences, and the list goes on and on. 5. You are opening yourself up to potential litigation. While bullying is not, strictly speaking, illegal it may be connected to a form of harassment or discrimination which can be subject to litigation. At the least attention will be taken up in tracking and proving a case. All this from denying bullyingoh, and lets add the personal guilt of not protecting ones tribe. (Date Range for Record Search: From 07/25/2021 To 03/04/2024)

Please include the full email chain and attachments relevant to any responsive documents to provide further context. To further narrow down the scope of the request, requester does not seek correspondence that merely forwards press clippings, such as news accounts or opinion pieces, newsletters, and published or docketed materials, if that correspondence has no comment or no substantive comment added by any party in the thread.The terms pertaining to, referring, relating, or concerning with respect to any given subject means anything that constitutes, contains, embodies, reflects, identifies, states, refers to, deals with, or is in any manner whatsoever pertinent to that subject.The term record means any written, recorded, or graphic matter of any nature whatsoever, regardless of how recorded, and whether original or copy, including, but not limited to, the following: memoranda, reports, expense reports, books, manuals, instructions, financial reports, working papers, records, notes, letters, notices, confirmations, telegrams, receipts, appraisals, pamphlets, magazines, newspapers, prospectuses, inter-office and intra-office communications, electronic mail (emails), MMS or SMS text messages, instant messages, messaging systems (such as iMessage, Microsoft Teams, WhatsApp, Telegram, Signal, Google Chat, Twitter direct messages, Lync, Slack, and Facebook Messenger), contracts, cables, telexes, notations of any type of conversation, telephone call, voicemail, meeting or other communication. Please comply fully with 5 U.S.C. § 552(b). Accordingly, without limitation to the foregoing, if any portion of this request is denied for any reason, please provide written notice of the records or portions of records that are being withheld and cite each specific exemption of the Freedom of Information Act on which the agency relies. Moreover, to the extent that responsive records may be withheld in part produce all reasonably segregable portions of those records. Additionally, please provide all responsive documents even if they are redacted in full. This request is primarily and fundamentally for non-commercial purposes. As an investigative columnist and author, my request is in the public interest to inform the public regarding the agency's operations voter issues ahead of the upcoming elections.

In March, we filed a FOIA request numbered 24-FOI-00324 for Amtrak Pacific Surfliner ridership by month for the months of 2021 and 2022 for all trips internal to San Diego County, which would be all trips between the stations of OLT - San Diego (Old Town) SAN - San Diego (Santa Fe Depot) OSD - Oceanside SOL - Solanas. The attached file was returned to us in .xls format. You will see that starting in October of 2022, the numbers jump tenfold. We believe this cannot have happened, especially because it does not follow the natural shape of pandemic recovery, but particularly because the trains resume the older numbers after July of 2023. We would like information that explains why the data for these months is ten times earlier data. If it is wrong, we would like the actual numbers for these months. And we would like data for the months of October, November and December of 2023. (Date Range for Record Search: From 01/01/2021 To 12/31/2023)

On page 18 of the FY23 Management Discussion and Analysis of Financial statements the following disclosure is made: Mechanical major capital expenditures in FY2023 included $100 million for overhauls and replacement of Amfleet cars (single-level passenger cars built in the 1970s and 1980s), $69 million for diesel locomotive acquisitions, $67 million for overhauls and modifications on Superliners (bi-level passenger cars built in the 1970s, early 1980s and 1990s and used primarily on Long Distance trains that do not operate over the NEC), $37 million for new or overhauls and modifications of other locomotives, sleeper and baggage cars, and $26 million for other passenger or baggage car overhauls and facilities repairs and improvements. For each dollar total that is disclosed (above), please provide an itemized list of each piece of equipment subject to an overhaul including the specific maintenance performed on each as the well as the dollar amount capitalized for each piece of equipment. By way of example, Amtrak's FY22-27 Service & Asset Line Plan categorizes overhauls by the following definitions-please indicate which overhaul "level" pertains to each overhauled railcar: Amtrak's Overhaul Cycle Level I (Every 4 years) The lightest overhaul includes complete rebuilding of trucks, HVAC units, brake valves, door operators and system critical components as well as heavy cleaning of carpeted surfaces and seat cushion replacement. Level II (Every 8 years) A Level I overhaul plus a complete replacement of all major components such as seats, diaphragms, windows and 480V trainline cabling. Level III (As needed) A Level II overhaul plus a complete interior upgrade or reconfiguration, including bathroom modules and any required modifications (Date Range for Record Search: From 09/02/2022 To 04/29/2024)

Dear FOIA Officer, Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, 5 U.S.C. § 552, and the implementing FOIA regulations of the agency, I respectfully request the following: All documents sufficient to detail all incurred expenses, costs, or receipts associated with the implementation or execution of Executive Order 14019 by the agency. All documents that identify the source or line of funding used for the expenses/expenditures associated with implementation or execution of Executive Order 14019. All legal opinions or memos surrounding Executive Order 14019 drafted, created, or retained by the agency. All documents, emails, or correspondence that include both the text of 'Executive Order 14019' OR 14019 AND 'Antideficiency Act'. All communications between the agency and Justin Levitt (justin.m.levitt@who.eop.gov), or Joseph Waldow (joseph.d.waldow@omb.eop.gov), or Justin Vail, Special Assistant to the President for Democracy and Civic Participation. Please search the inboxes of personnel assigned to the agencys Office of General Counsel (or the agencys equivalent) as the primary custodians. The time period for this request is from 12:01 PM EST on January 20, 2021, to the present date. To further narrow down the scope of the request, requester does not seek correspondence that merely forwards press clippings, such as news accounts or opinion pieces, newsletters, and published or docketed materials, if that correspondence has no comment or no substantive comment added by any party in the thread.The terms pertaining to, referring, relating, or concerning with respect to any given subject means anything that constitutes, contains, embodies, reflects, identifies, states, refers to, deals with, or is in any manner whatsoever pertinent to that subject.The term record means any written, recorded, or graphic matter of any nature whatsoever, regardless of how recorded, and whether original or copy, including, but not limited to, the following: memoranda, reports, expense reports, books, manuals, instructions, financial reports, working papers, records, notes, letters, notices, confirmations, telegrams, receipts, appraisals, pamphlets, magazines, newspapers, prospectuses, inter-office and intra-office communications, electronic mail (emails), MMS or SMS text messages, instant messages, messaging systems (such as iMessage, Microsoft Teams, WhatsApp, Telegram, Signal, Google Chat, Twitter direct messages, Lync, Slack, and Facebook Messenger), contracts, cables, telexes, notations of any type of conversation, telephone call, voicemail, meeting or other communication. Please comply fully with 5 U.S.C. § 552(b). Accordingly, without limitation to the foregoing, if any portion of this request is denied for any reason, please provide written notice of the records or portions of records that are being withheld and cite each specific exemption of the Freedom of Information Act on which the agency relies. Moreover, to the extent that responsive records may be withheld in part produce all reasonably segregable portions of those records. Additionally, please provide all responsive documents even if they are redacted in full. This request is primarily and fundamentally for non-commercial purposes. As an investigative columnist and author, my request is in the public interest to inform the public regarding the agency's operations voter issues ahead of the upcoming elections.

We had an opportunity to talk with a lovely young woman that was disembarking at one of these terminals who had overheard a disturbing conversation amongst the engineer/conductor/attendant while boarding the train for our 6:45am CDT departure. They had stated there was something funny going on with the power, but were going to push thru and complete the route to Pontiac and "they can deal with it there". Right before the train lost power, we did smell a burning smell, similar to that of burning rubber/electrical. This is a huge concern and a glaring red flag on proper pre-trip inspections for Amtrak. On that note, I am requesting, in writing, the following information (FOIA request email address is cc'd above): Description of Records Sought: - Name and Title of all crew operating the Amtrak Wolverine 350 on May 19, 2024 at 6:45am CDT. - Any grievances filed against the above requested crew members operating the Amtrak Wolverine 350 on May 19, 2024 at 6:45am CDT. - Any disciplinary action taken against the above requested crew members operating the Amtrak Wolverine 350 on May 19, 2024 at 6:45am CDT. - 30 days worth of Maintenance/Engineering records and pre-trip inspection for the Amtrak Wolverine 350 that was in use on May 19, 2024 @ 6:45am CDT. **It is known that the Wolverines do return trips with others engines/cars, but you know exactly what I want and what I'm asking for - the engine and car records for the engine that was responsible for the power failure of Wolverine 350 on May 19, 2024 at 9:20am** Don't forget the pre-trip inspection records for the actual day of May 19, 2024 @ 6:45am CDT as well. Fee category: IV Fee waiver requested in accordance with 49 CFR 701.11 paragraph (k)(2)(i) (Date Range for Record Search: From 04/20/2024 To 05/20/2024)

In response to FOI-24-00415 Managements proposed Strategic Blueprint document was provided. This document was presented to the Board of Directors by Exec. Vice President Dennis Newman. The Board of Directors approved this document on September 27, 2023. This is a request for records under the Freedom of Information Act, 5 U.S.C. § 552. I request a copy of Amtraks critical incident stress plan approved by the Federal Railroad Administration. I am referring to the plan submitted to the FRA pursuant to 49 CFR Part 272, which required railroads to submit these plans no later than 12 months after June 23, 2014. If Amtrak has since submitted a modified plan for approval, I request Amtraks most recent modified critical incident stress plan approved by the FRA. Please provide these records in electronic format, preferably PDF. I am not requesting these records for commercial purposes, and I am a member of the media. I request a fee waiver because these records are being sought to contribute to public understanding of the operations or activities of the government. If my fee waiver is denied, I ask that you contact me in advance with the estimated cost. I am willing to pay up to $20 in fees. If you have any questions, feel free to contact me at evespa@northcarolinahealthnews.org or by cell phone at (704) 493-4606. Thank you.

Dear FOIA Officer, Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, 5 U.S.C. § 552, and the implementing FOIA regulations of the agency, I respectfully request the following: Documents sufficient to to account for all GLOMAR FOIA responses issued by the agency from 1 January, 2024 to present, along with a copy of the original FOIA request the GLOMAR was issued in response to. Search Instructions: Please limit all searches in response to this Request from January 1, 2024, to the present. Please include the full email chain and attachments relevant to any responsive documents to provide further context. To further narrow down the scope of the request, requester does not seek correspondence that merely forwards press clippings, such as news accounts or opinion pieces, newsletters, and published or docketed materials, if that correspondence has no comment or no substantive comment added by any party in the thread. The terms pertaining to, referring, relating, or concerning with respect to any given subject means anything that constitutes, contains, embodies, reflects, identifies, states, refers to, deals with, or is in any manner whatsoever pertinent to that subject.The term record means any written, recorded, or graphic matter of any nature whatsoever, regardless of how recorded, and whether original or copy, including, but not limited to, the following: memoranda, reports, expense reports, books, manuals, instructions, financial reports, working papers, records, notes, letters, notices, confirmations, telegrams, receipts, appraisals, pamphlets, magazines, newspapers, prospectuses, inter-office and intra-office communications, electronic mail (emails), MMS or SMS text messages, instant messages, messaging systems (such as iMessage, Microsoft Teams, WhatsApp, Telegram, Signal, Google Chat, Twitter direct messages, Lync, Slack, and Facebook Messenger), contracts, cables, telexes, notations of any type of conversation, telephone call, voicemail, meeting or other communication. Please comply fully with 5 U.S.C. § 552(b). Accordingly, without limitation to the foregoing, if any portion of this request is denied for any reason, please provide written notice of the records or portions of records that are being withheld and cite each specific exemption of the Freedom of Information Act on which the agency relies. Moreover, to the extent that responsive records may be withheld in part produce all reasonably segregable portions of those records. Additionally, please provide all responsive documents even if they are redacted in full. This request is primarily and fundamentally for non-commercial purposes. As an investigative columnist and author, my request is in the public interest to inform the public regarding the agency's policies and procedures on the national stage relevant to the agency's operations such as hiring, personnel retention, fraud waste and abuse, etc.

This FOIA request is being submitted on behalf of Ms. Dinahetta Lewis and her two minor children, Jurnee Lewis and Jace Lewis, and Ms. Lillian Andrews and concern an event which occurred on June 10, 2024 at or about 11:20 p.m. aboard Amtrak Train Number 79, departing Union Station, Washington, DC and traveling to Cary, North Carolina. At approximately 11: 20 a.m. on June 10, 2024 passengers aboard Train Number 79 suffered what was described by many people aboard this train as a huge, tremendous, forceful, and violent jerking, lurching and buckling motion/movement, which caused people to lose their balance, fall forwards, backwards and to each and every side. One person was told by a train conductor that it was due to an engine being connected to the train, but no confirmation of this has as of yet been obtainable. This FOIA request includes, but is not necessarily limited to: Any and all written incident reports regarding this violent lurching event. Any and all written reports regarding the cause of this violent lurching event. Any and all written reports submitted by any and all passengers, including but not limited to, Ms. Dinahetta Lewis and Ms. Lillian Andrews, regarding this violent lurching event. Any and all calls, or written reports of calls, for ambulance service for any and all passengers deboarding Train Number 79 at the Amtrak train station located in Occoquan, Virginia. Any and all train conductor reports regarding this violent lurching event. Any and all Engineer reports regarding this violent lurching event. Any and all Amtrak maintenance records for Train Number 79 for the time period of May 1, 2024 through June 18, 2024. Copies of any and all videotape or digital recordings made aboard Amtrak Train Number 79 during the time period of 10:00 a.m. to 4:00 pm on June 10, 2024. Any and all written reports/information filed by/submitted by, Amtrak Conductor Number 91, who was working on board Train Number 79 at the time of this violent lurching event, including the name of Conductor No. 91. Any and all information in the possession of Amtrak regarding Ms. Dinahetta Lewis, Ms. Lillian Andrews, Miss Jurnee Lewis and Mr. Jace Lewis regarding this June 10, 2024 event.  (Date Range for Record Search: From 05/01/2024 To 06/18/2024)

The Human Rights Defense Center (HRDC) makes this request pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, 5 U.S.C. § 552, et seq. HRDC is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization that publishes two journals and multiple books reporting on prisons, jails and other detention facilities. HRDC requests a fee waiver for this request. Prior to a name change approved by the Secretary of State in Washington in 2009, HRDC was known as Prison Legal News. Documents Requested HRDC is seeking records of all FOIA litigation against the Amtrak Police Department and/or its employees or agents where the agency and/or its insurers paid $1,000 or more to resolve claims. These payments include but are not limited to settlements, damages, attorney fee awards, and sanctions, irrespective of the identity of the plaintiff or claimant. Specifically, HRDC requests the following records, provided in electronic native format where possible, and otherwise in electronic format: 1.	Records, regardless of physical form or characteristics, sufficient to show for all claims or lawsuits brought against the Amtrak Police Department and/or any of its agents or employees in which payments totaling $1,000 or more were disbursed from July 11, 2014 to the present: 	The name of all parties involved; 	The case or claim number; 	The jurisdiction in which the case or claim was brought (e.g., U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia, D.C. Superior Court, etc.); 	The date of resolution; 	The amount of money involved in the resolution and to whom it was paid, 2.	For each case or claim detailed above: 	The complaint or claim form and any amended versions; 	The verdict form, final judgment, settlement agreement, consent decree, or other paper that resolved the case. Fee Waiver Requested HRDC requests a waiver of fees under 5 U.S.C. §§ 552(a)(4)(A)(ii)(II) and (iii), as HRDC is a member of the news media and disclosure of the requested information is in the public interest. HRDC is the publisher of Prison Legal News and Criminal Legal News, as well as several books about the criminal justice system and legal issues affecting prisoners. Prison Legal News is a legal journal that reports news and litigation concerning carceral facilities. PLN covers corrections news and analysis and criminal justice-related issues on a national level. PLN has published monthly since 1990 and has approximately 9,000 subscribers in all 50 states. Based on reader survey results the estimated actual readership is around ten times that number. PLNs subscribers include lawyers, journalists, judges, courts, public libraries and universities. PLN also maintains a website that receives approximately 100,000 visitors per month based on site analytics. Criminal Legal News is a legal journal. HRDC launched the inaugural issue in December 2017. CLN reports on criminal law decisions from all 50 states and the federal court system, focusing on legal developments affecting the fact and duration of confine (Date Range for Record Search: From 08/08/2014 To 08/08/2024)

Dear Inspector General, I am writing to request your assistance in obtaining a copy of the insurance report related to an incident that occurred on November 18, 2017, involving the National Railroad Passenger Corporation (Amtrak). This incident resulted in severe injuries while I was operating a Taylor-Dunn Bigfoot cart. Dear FOIA Officer, Under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), I am requesting records related to track utilization, dwell times, and interagency coordination at New York Penn Station. This request is intended to gather data that will help evaluate operational inefficiencies at Penn Station, specifically those related to track utilization, dwell times, and interagency coordination challenges. These inefficiencies are critical to understanding the potential benefits of implementing through-running services, which could provide a long-term solution to address track conflicts and delays arising from the existing stub-end terminal model. 1. Track Utilization Reports: Daily track utilization reports for tracks 121 during peak hours (6:00 AM to 10:00 AM and 4:00 PM to 8:00 PM) from January 1, 2023, to the present. These reports should include: Track number Train number Scheduled arrival and departure times Actual arrival and departure times Duration of track occupancy Additionally, if available, any reports related to track utilization during high-stress periods, such as public holidays or large-scale events. 2. Dwell Time Analysis: Monthly average dwell time reports for Amtrak trains at Penn Station from January 1, 2023, to the present. These reports should include: Train number Origin and destination Scheduled dwell time Actual dwell time Any notes on factors contributing to extended dwell times 3. Track Conflict and Delay Reports: Reports or analyses from January 1, 2023, to the present that document instances of track conflicts, platform unavailability, or delays due to track unavailability. These reports should include: Date and time of conflict Tracks involved Trains affected Duration of delay Any notes on resolution or mitigation measures 4. Interagency Coordination Communications: Internal communications, meeting notes, or reports from Amtrak, NJ Transit, and LIRR from January 1, 2023, to the present discussing operational coordination issues caused by track conflicts or capacity limitations at Penn Station. Please provide these records in a digital format, preferably as Excel spreadsheets or CSV files where applicable. If these formats are not feasible, I am open to receiving the records in another digital format. (Date Range for Record Search: From 01/01/2023 To 09/10/2024)

Dear FOIA Officer, Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, 5 U.S.C. § 552, and the implementing FOIA regulations of the agency, I respectfully request the following: Documents sufficient to to account for all documents or finalized reports submitted to the U.S. Government Accountability Office ('GAO') mentioning 'Antideficiency Act' or 'Antideficiency Act Report'. Search Instructions: Please limit all searches in response to this Request from January 1, 2021, to the present. Please include the full email chain and attachments relevant to any responsive documents to provide further context. To further narrow down the scope of the request, requester does not seek correspondence that merely forwards press clippings, such as news accounts or opinion pieces, newsletters, and published or docketed materials, if that correspondence has no comment or no substantive comment added by any party in the thread. The terms pertaining to, referring, relating, or concerning with respect to any given subject means anything that constitutes, contains, embodies, reflects, identifies, states, refers to, deals with, or is in any manner whatsoever pertinent to that subject.The term record means any written, recorded, or graphic matter of any nature whatsoever, regardless of how recorded, and whether original or copy, including, but not limited to, the following: memoranda, reports, expense reports, books, manuals, instructions, financial reports, working papers, records, notes, letters, notices, confirmations, telegrams, receipts, appraisals, pamphlets, magazines, newspapers, prospectuses, inter-office and intra-office communications, electronic mail (emails), MMS or SMS text messages, instant messages, messaging systems (such as iMessage, Microsoft Teams, WhatsApp, Telegram, Signal, Google Chat, Twitter direct messages, Lync, Slack, and Facebook Messenger), contracts, cables, telexes, notations of any type of conversation, telephone call, voicemail, meeting or other communication. Please comply fully with 5 U.S.C. § 552(b). Accordingly, without limitation to the foregoing, if any portion of this request is denied for any reason, please provide written notice of the records or portions of records that are being withheld and cite each specific exemption of the Freedom of Information Act on which the agency relies. Moreover, to the extent that responsive records may be withheld in part produce all reasonably segregable portions of those records. Additionally, please provide all responsive documents even if they are redacted in full. This request is primarily and fundamentally for non-commercial purposes. As an investigative columnist and author, my request is in the public interest to inform the public regarding the agency's policies and procedures on the national stage relevant to domestic policy issues.
