The one email in your chief FOIA officer's email spam folder or equivalent which was received nearest and before October 19, 2024, midnight Eastern time, regardless of subject matter. 3. The one email in your chief FOIA officer's sent email folder or equivalent which was sent nearest and before October 19, 2024, midnight Eastern time, regardless of subject matter. 4. The total full-time equivalent count of people who work for your FOIA office as of October 19, 2024. This request is expressly limited to Amtrak's own FOIA office. Please do not refer it to any other agency or division. This request is expressly not a Privacy Act request, and no PA waiver will be provided. Please provide the email records in EML, Maildir, MBOX, MIX, MSG, or PST format only  not PDF, Word, image, etc  including all metadata (e.g. full email headers as received/sent) and attachments, without alteration other than narrowly tailored electronic redaction of specifically claimed exemptions that do not affect any part of non exempt information (and, in particular, without rasterization). Please provide the fourth record as a statement in your response letter, or at your option, as the most readily available record, in original electronic format as currently stored on your computer systems, which includes that information. Please provide all records either as individual files, or as an unencrypted ZIP file, uploaded to MuckRock. Do not apply any encryption, DRM, or other restriction. I request fee waiver, because * Fiat Fiendum is a 501(c)(3) non-profit; * this request is for public interest, non-commercial purposes; * these records would give a snapshot of insight into the everyday processes of FOIA offices; and * these records are being requested in order to conduct a government-wide audit of agencies' FOIA compliance. In the event that you deny fee waiver, please process this request as-is, because I will not agree to any fees. Please be sure to provide: * 5 USC 552(a)(6)(A)(i)(II) FOIA Public Liaison information * 5 USC 552(a)(6)(A)(i)(III)(aa) appeal information * 5 USC 552(a)(6)(A)(i)(III)(bb) OGIS information * 5 USC 552(a)(7)(A) tracking number * 5 USC 552(a)(7)(B)(ii) completion ETA Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires. Sincerely, Sai President, Fiat Fiendum, Inc. P.S. Sai is my full legal name.

In FY24, Amtrak completed extensive "wreck repairs" on about a dozen bi-level Superliner cars within the long-distance network. This FOIA request seeks Amtrak's policies and procedures regarding the "economic limit of repair" concerning the overhaul, wreck repair, or complete rebuilding of railcars. These policies and procedures likely involve a collaborative effort between Amtrak Finance, Capital Delivery, and the Mechanical Department, which carries out these repair programs. Specifically, this request inquires about the criteria that determine the investment limit for repairing a railcar. It questions how the potential for incremental revenue influences the evaluation and decision-making process. Additionally, it asks about the timeline for considering future revenue and operating cost benefits in the evaluation, as well as the interest rate used for "discounted cash flow" (DCF) analysis. (Date Range for Record Search: From 10/01/2023 To 11/06/2024)

The statement on page 41 of Amtrak's FY24-28 Five-Year Plans pertains to obtaining insights into what specifically has been accomplished and what remains to be done: During FY23, Amtrak officially began the next major milestone in its multi-year fleet refurbishment initiative. After interior updates of Acela, Amfleet, and Horizon equipment in recent years, the company initiated the interior refurbishment of the bi-level Superliner fleet, which operates on nine of the 15 Long Distance routes. The Superliner project aims to enhance nearly 400 passenger cars, with over 100 already refreshed and in revenue service. This phase also expanded the refurbishment to include Sleeping Cars, Dining Cars, and Superliner bi-level Sightseer Lounges." "The refresh of all Viewliner I Sleeping Cars is set to begin in 2024, aligning the in-room experience with the new Viewliner II Sleeping Cars, both operating on Eastern routes with single-level equipment. Please provide the following in relation to this statement: A list of the Viewliner I car numbers that were refreshed in FY24 and those scheduled for refresh in FY25. Detail the scope of work completed during a refresh targeted towards aligning the in-room experience with the Viewliner II sleeping cars. Provide an inventory of the number of Superliner sleeping cars, coaches, dining cars, diner lounges, sleeper dormitories, and coaches that have been refreshed as of the end of FY24, the number remaining, and the timeline to complete the refurbishment programs for both the Superliner and Viewliner I. (Date Range for Record Search: From 10/01/2023 To 11/06/2024)

Section 7101 pertains solely to "Grants to the National Railroad Passenger Corporation". Amtrak management's compensation is comprised of a base salary and a schedule of benefits which includes participation in long-term and short-term incentive compensation schemes that provide for payments earned due to the attainment of various business-related goals and objectives. This is a follow-up to 25-FOI-00071 As outlined in the attached, in the "General & Legislative Annual Report & Fiscal Year 2024 Grant Request" Amtrak reported that new long-distance fleet would require an investment of approximately $4.2 billion. One year later, in the "General and Legislative Annual Report & Fiscal Year 2025 Grant Request" Amtrak reports the cost of this procurement has escalated from $4.2 billion to $7.0 billion. Page 100 of the Fiscal Year 2025 report indicates that log-distance fleet will be funded from supplemental IIJA funds. However, the information provided in response to 25-FOI-00071 suggests that of the approximately $22 billion in supplemental funds only $4.3 billion remains unobligated. There appears to be only $4.3 billion in IIJA supplemental funding to address what is now a $7 billion long-distance fleet procurement. Please provide insight as to Amtrak's current expectations regarding how the bi-level RFP will be funded given the reported need for $7 billion to invest but little more than $4 billion uto obligate. see attached for further detail  (Date Range for Record Search: From 01/01/2023 To 11/21/2024)

From June 1, 2023 through January 1, 2024, I request a sample of up to 10 completed FOIA case files from your offices FOIA tracking system where scope clarification occurred. Each case must have all of: (1) a written agency response seeking clarification about the scope of records sought; (2) a written requester response that clarified the request; (3) a final determination letter; and (4) a case closure date within the specified date range. For each of these case files, I seek only: (1) the initial FOIA request; (2) the agency's scope clarification letter (or email or similar record); (3) the requester's clarification response or the request as it was ultimately processed; (4) and the final determination letter. Specifically, for a sample of requests where clarification was needed, Im looking for the original request, the rationale for clarification, and the clarified request. I am studying how agencies and requesters work together to clarify and refine requests, so I need only the substance of these communications, not any personally identifying details. To reduce processing time and protect privacy: please exclude any Privacy Act requests, cases where clarification was sought solely about fees, and cases where the requester never responded with clarification. And please redact all personal information (names, addresses, emails, phone numbers). If your office cannot find 10 completed case files with these criteria, please send as many case files as you can find that do.

This is a follow-up question to the work product provided in response to 25-FOI-00081 requesting a copy of the unit specific fleet equipment report that FRA requires to be filed 45 days after the close of Amtrak's fiscal year. There are quite a few irregularities in the data reported to FRA raising legitimate questions regarding the accuracy and credibility of the data reported. By way of example, attached is a pdf listing all pieces of equipment either overhauled or having brake tests performed by Amtrak mechanical forces. Included are cars released subsequent to wreck repairs being performed. All of this equipment is reported as "inactive" to FRA. All but one unit is reported as "stored". Of the "stored" cars 11 are reported as "wrecked" despite the fact that this equipment was released from maintenance facilities such as Beech Grove during the last half of FY24. Collectively, this makes no sense. Separately, there are locomotives that were overhauled in FY24 that are not reported to FRA as even existing. Unit numbers 517 and 579 were released from the diesel switcher overhaul program in Feb 2024 and Sep 2024, respectively, but are omitted from the report to FRA. Similarly, coach 25807 was released from overhaul during Jun 2024 but is not reported to FRA as an existing asset. Is FRA aware of these data irregularities? Has Amtrak submitted a corrected report? If so, please provide a copy of the corrected report?  (Date Range for Record Search: From 10/01/2023 To 12/17/2024)

Dear FOIA Officer, Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, 5 U.S.C. § 552, and the implementing FOIA regulations of the agency, I respectfully request the following: Documents sufficient to account for: 1) Documentation or records identifying any personnel who transitioned from Schedule C appointments to SES positions within the last year, including the dates and circumstances of such transitions. 2) A complete list of all SES employees hired in the last year, or promoted to SES in the last year. The resume provided by the individual to the agency in connection with determining the appropriate salary for the individual, or if that is not available, a recent resume contained within the agency's records. Copies of any SF-50 forms for the individual reflecting any change in position, title, or salary, including when the employee starts or leaves a position. 3) The most recent organizational and hierarchy charts published or disseminated interally by the agency or subordinate organizational entity. Search Instructions: Please limit all searches in response to this Request from January 1, 2024, to the present. Please include the full email chain and attachments relevant to any responsive documents to provide further context. To further narrow down the scope of the request, requester does not seek correspondence that merely forwards press clippings, such as news accounts or opinion pieces, newsletters, and published or docketed materials, if that correspondence has no comment or no substantive comment added by any party in the thread. The terms pertaining to, referring, relating, or concerning with respect to any given subject means anything that constitutes, contains, embodies, reflects, identifies, states, refers to, deals with, or is in any manner whatsoever pertinent to that subject.The term record means any written, recorded, or graphic matter of any nature whatsoever, regardless of how recorded, and whether original or copy, including, but not limited to, the following: memoranda, reports, expense reports, books, manuals, instructions, financial reports, working papers, records, notes, letters, notices, confirmations, telegrams, receipts, appraisals, pamphlets, magazines, newspapers, prospectuses, inter-office and intra-office communications, electronic mail (emails), MMS or SMS text messages, instant messages, messaging systems (such as iMessage, Microsoft Teams, WhatsApp, Telegram, Signal, Google Chat, Twitter direct messages, Lync, Slack, and Facebook Messenger), contracts, cables, telexes, notations of any type of conversation, telephone call, voicemail, meeting or other communication. Please comply fully with 5 U.S.C. § 552(b). Accordingly, without limitation to the foregoing, if any portion of this request is denied for any reason, please provide written notice of the records or portions of records that are being withheld and cite each specific exemption of the Freedom of Information Act on which the agency relies. Moreover, to the extent that responsive records may be withheld in part produce all reasonably segregable portions of those records. Additionally, please provide all responsive documents even if they are redacted in full. This request is primarily and fundamentally for non-commercial purposes. As an investigative columnist and author, my request is in the public interest to inform the public regarding the agency's policies and procedures on the national stage relevant to domestic policy issues.

Subject: FOIA Request: Speed limit data by segment along Amtrak routes Hello, Through this FOIA request, I am looking to obtain data for speed limits by rail segment along each Amtrak route. However, this OSM dataset is incomplete  as shown by the grey segments. Therefore, I am requesting a complete dataset of speed limits along each Amtrak route. If available, I would appreciate any additional attributes such as track grade and locomotive fuel/energy usage by segment. Ideally, this data would be included as attributes to a shapefile for each route, but other formats are acceptable. This data will support my research at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, sponsored by the National Science Foundation, which would correspond to Fee Category III: Educational or Noncommercial Scientific Institutions. I am willing to pay up to $100.00 for processing fees; please let me know if fees will exceed this amount. If you need any additional information, please do not hesitate to contact me at aswhite@mit.edu or 717.503.5649. Thank you! Best regards, Andrew Scott White Graduate Research Fellow Massachusetts Institute of Technology

In November 2024 Amtrak's Jim Blair advised Florida Department of Transportation that Amtrak would not relocate its Miami station from Hialeah to the Miami Intermodal Center. As recently as March 16, 2024 Amtrak had advised Congress in its General and Legislative Report & FY2025 Grant Request that the relocation was a certainty. Given that Amtrak executed a contractual agreement with Florida DOT in 2013 to facilitate operation to the Intermodal Center it is inconceivable how, once a certainty less than one year ago, Amtrak has reversed what Floridian's believed to be a commitment. The $2 billion Miami Intermodal Center was constructed at significant cost to Floridians. A fully equipped Amtrak station was constructed within this facility. Once again, I request a copy of Mr. Blair's June 7, 2024 email to Kim Holland at FDOT outlining Amtrak's terms and conditions for relocating. A failure to provide an unreacted copy of this document will be interpreted as a failure of Amtrak leadership to be transparent. Additionally, a copy of an UNREDACTED financial and economic analysis supporting Amtrak's reversal is requested. A failure to provide an unredacted document will lead to the conclusion that Amtrak is not transparent. This is a fraught moment for Amtrak with the FY2025 budget process underway. Certainly, not a wise moment to raise questions in the minds of Florida's very large Congressional delegation regarding the value of Amtrak to the state.  (Date Range for Record Search: From 01/01/2024 To 02/13/2025)

These are follow-up questions for 25-FOI-00202. Incremental train & engine crew labor is projected to increase by 10% which is entirely attributed to operating both long distance trains 4 miles beyond the Hialeah station (8 miles RT). Similarly, incremental on-board labor is projected to increase by 10% as well for the same reason. These increased incremental costs require further explanation as inbound trains will run through to the airport (avoiding Hialeah) from Hollywood to discharge passengers and then return 4 miles to Hialeah for servicing. Similarly, trains will reposition from Hialeah servicing to the airport (4 miles) for passenger boarding and departure north running non-stop to Hollywood, FL. Please explain the reason behind increased "Reservation and Call Centers? What increased manpower is required to support an average of 52 passengers per calendar day fully acknowledging that many transactions are fully automated and paperless. Does Amtrak actually incur incremental cash costs of $10.10 cents per passenger? Please explain. Station and Facility costs for both long-distance trains are projected to increase by fully 27% from $2.2 million to $2.8 million. Please provide an explanation behind this increase. Amtrak will avoid on-going operating costs for the Hialeah station--have they been incorporated in this analysis and how much? What comprises the $600,000 in additional incremental annual costs. Please reveal the rental FDOT expects Amtrak to pay? What are the other components of this increase? Please provide a clear and concise explanation regarding what "initial capital improvements" are required at the MIC? Additional explanation would appear to be in order regarding what has changed over the past twelve years. Amtrak executed a contract amendment with FDOT in 2013 to provide contractual authority for Amtrak to operate into the Miami Intermodal Center. Moreover, Amtrak operated at least one test train to the Center subsequent to the highway bypass being installed by FDOT. Eleven months ago, Amtrak reported to Congress in the General and Legislative Annual Report & FY 2025 Grant Request that, " The company does expect to move its Miami station stop, served by the Silver Star and Silver Meteor, from the current location (next to a freight railroad yard in the Hialeah neighborhood) to the Miami Intermodal Center (MIC) at Miami International Airport. There are legitimate concerns, in Florida, regarding whether these estimates have been "manufactured" to justify a preordained decision. To illustrate, Amtrak submitted an ADA Progress Report to the US Department of Justice reporting progress in upgrading the accessibility of facilities. Although the Congressional report advised Senators and House members that the relocation was imminent, the ADA report to DOJ reported that Amtrak had, prior to May 1, 2024, executed a construction contract to upgrade Hialeah thus apparently dooming the relocation. (Date Range for Record Search: From 01/01/2024 To 02/14/2025)

This is a second follow-up question pertaining to the work product provided as part of 25-FOI-00202. All class 1 railroads including Amtrak are required to submit employee compensation data to the Surface Transportation Board. Attached is a recap of reporting for the full calendar year 2023 for each railroad's train & engine employees. According to this data (sourced from the STB website), Amtrak's train and engine crew employees were paid an average of $47.11 per service hour during calendar year 2023 (which includes the first quarter of Amtrak's FY25 accounting year). Even if one adds fringe benefits (e.g. amtrak portion of retirement taxes, health & welfare, medicare, etc.) it is very difficult to reconcile how the incremental t&e labor costs to operate an additional 4 miles from Hialeah to the Miami Airport totals the $2.2 million that Amtrak FP&A has estimated. Please provide insight as to how the STB wage data for train & engine crews reconciles to the $2.2 million dollar projection provided as part of 25-FOI-00202. (Date Range for Record Search: From 01/01/2023 To 02/14/2025)
HARVARD UNIVERSITY,,, MAJOR GENERAL,,, PLAT

On February 15, 2025 I rode train #163 from Boston (departed 11:30 a.m.) During the ride I was informed my ticket was for March 15, 2025 (not Feb 15th). I was not aware of this mistake as all my other travel arrangements were around this weekend including my train ticket NYC to DC on Feb 17th. The main conductor, after speaking to reservations stated I would need to pay $500 for a first class ticket as there were no other tickets available. I had an important event to attend in NYC by 5 p.m. and I requested to just remain in the dining for the duration of the trip using my March 15th ticket which was an error with date. The conductor refused and stated he would contact railroad police to exit me from the train in New Haven CT. The police were at the stop and I left the train on my own even though I think it was much to do about a simple mistake and me seated in the dining car should not have been an issue. The conductor stated he would be doing a report and the railroad police took my info and brought me to the ticket window to purchase new tickets and I assume they have done a report as well. I would like under the FOIA to obtain both the conductors report and the police report and any other report concerning this matter on Feb, 15, 2025. Thank You.. (Date Range for Record Search: From 02/15/2025 To 02/16/2025)

Please see attached request. Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, 5 U.S.C. § 552, we write on behalf of Reservoir Hill Association (RHA) to request agency records held by Amtrak regarding the Frederick Douglass Tunnel Project Community Investment Program (the CIP). Unless otherwise indicated, the timeframe for the requested records covers the period of time beginning on January 1, 2023 through the date of your response (request period). The term record includes, but is not limited to, books, papers, files, accounts, writings, including drafts and memorializations of conversations; all communications preserved in electronic or written form, such as correspondences, emails, documents, data, videotapes, audio tapes, faxes, files, guidances, guidelines, analyses, memoranda, agreements, notes, orders, policies, procedures, legal opinions, protocols, reports, rules, or manuals; and other items, regardless of format or physical characteristics, that are developed or received by a public agency, or by a private contractor for a public agency, and that are preserved for their informational value or as evidence of the organization or operation of the public agency. We make the following specific requests: 1.	All records or communications during the request period regarding distribution, implementation, administration, and/or oversight of the CIP, including but not limited to: a.	Any records of a potential division of funds among West Baltimore communities, including but not limited to considerations of equity, need-based criteria, or specific geographic allocations; b.	Decisions or decision-making processes regarding considered fund administrators who will oversee the management of the $2.75M Preservation Grant Fund and broader $50M CIP; c.	Any policies, procedures, or criteria governing the distribution of and eligibility criteria for CIP funds; d.	Any deliberations regarding the types of projects eligible for CIP dollars, including proposals and justifications for inclusion or exclusion of project categories; and e.	Any priority lists, scoring rubrics, or evaluative metrics used to assess project proposals. 2.	Reports or analyses on how CIP funds have been spent or are projected to be spent. 3.	Records relating to the timing of the distribution of CIP dollars, including but not limited to the timeline of and process for the launch of the CIPs Community Grant and Direct Investments Programs, and the issuance of the formal notice of funding opportunity (NOFO). 4.	Records relating to the drafting, approval, and issuance of the NOFO, including any communications with stakeholders, public input processes, and responses to inquire about the NOFO.

FOIA Coordinator, Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, 5 U.S.C. § 552 et seq., I write to request a copy of all full time employees' first, middle (if available) and last names, including their job title/position, their office location (city and state only), date of hire and email address. Please provide this information in an electronic format such as Excel or .csv. If these records do not exist in the requested format, please send them in the form in which they are held. If you do not maintain these public records, please let me know who does and include the proper custodian's contact information pursuant to to 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(3)(B). As provided by the Act, I will expect your response within twenty (20) business days. If there is a backlog in your office or you feel this request will take more than 20 business days to complete, please contact me at your earliest convenience to advise how much extra time will be needed to fully respond to my request. If you believe this information is not public, or choose to deny this request, I ask that you immediately notify me and provide the specific statutory exemption(s) upon which you rely. If part of the information is public and part is not, please provide all segregable portions of otherwise exempt material. Thank you for your assistance.
